castItem.role: INTRODUCTORY NOTE
“ The Tyranny of Tears
castItem.roleDesc: " a comedy of the emotions , is most ingeniously

castItem.role: constructed on the simplest lines ; it is a triumph of the commonplace
Played virtually by five characters
castItem.roleDesc: and with but one change of scene

castItem.role: it has that specious appearance of ease which is due to dexterity of
craftsmanship . It is refreshing
castItem.roleDesc: free from theatrical expedients , and

castItem.role: save perhaps for the somewhat accelerated wooing in Act Four
castItem.roleDesc: knots

castItem.role: which we are accustomed to see snipped by the scissors of an erratic
fate are here gently untangled by the fingers of probability . The germ
of it
castItem.roleDesc: a matter of fortunate selection , is a human foible so universal

castItem.role: that if a man is not conscious of it in his own proper person
castItem.roleDesc: he has

castItem.role: not failed to smile over it among his neighbors : that combination of
fondness and egoism out of which tyranny is legitimately born . This is
the keynote ; it announces itself speedily upon the raising of the
curtain
castItem.roleDesc: and it is never for a moment after obscured by those modern

castItem.role: subtilties calculated to provoke discussion among the elect . The
hearer equipped with ordinary experience finds himself listening to it
with an acquiescent stream of running comment . He knows this alphabet
It spells familiar words
castItem.roleDesc: and they come frequently . Here are

castItem.role: commonplaces which he has failed perhaps to formulate ; but now they
flash upon the inward eye with a convincing vividness . This
castItem.roleDesc: he sees

castItem.role: at once
castItem.roleDesc: is a picture of pink and white tyranny , the triumph of the

castItem.role: weak . Domestic life has been caught and fixed at the culmination of a
strain : one of those dramatic moments when the cord snaps because it
has been for a long time fraying . One party to the contract has drawn
up a code and imposed it upon his mate . The tyrant has some piquancy ;
she disarms suspicion because
castItem.roleDesc: although a despot , she is masquerading

castItem.role: as something else . Another sort of bully we know : the buckram female
loud-voiced , militant , announcing herself , like the mosquito , by a
vicious trumpeting . Invulnerability sits on her helm ; her armor clanks
a little while she strides . But this new tyrant wears another mien
Behold her ! a soft-cheeked
castItem.roleDesc: gentle-handed ministrant , who would have

castItem.role: husbands happy
castItem.roleDesc: provided they show the chivalrous courtesy of becoming

castItem.role: so in woman 's way . She knows the rules of the game according as her
sex interprets them
castItem.roleDesc: and it never enters her ingenuous mind that “ in

castItem.role: marriage there are two ideals to be realized . ” Thus does she make her
gentle progress
castItem.roleDesc: the victim beside her crowned with garlands , but yet

castItem.role: a victim . She is the arch destroyer
castItem.roleDesc: the juggernaut in muslin

castItem.role: As soon , therefore , as she is recognized , there is a great pricking-up
of ears all over the house . Few are they whose withers are unwrung
Every man among them
castItem.roleDesc: primed with his own warfare or that of some

castItem.role: defeated chum
castItem.roleDesc: settles down to the play , and wives follow suit with a

castItem.role: guilty sense that such things are
castItem.roleDesc: though “ not , thank heaven ! under

castItem.role: roof of mine . ”
A sly humor runs through the piece like a warm-colored thread
castItem.roleDesc: a humor

castItem.role: always faithful to those universal traits that make us kin . It asserts
itself robustly from time to time , once , for a notable instance , in
the fact that Parbury is moderately well content in his fool 's
paradise until Gunning appears to beckon him out of it . Heretofore he
has accepted his experience like a chronic indigestion or a lameness
to which he was born ; but now comes another man like unto himself
castItem.roleDesc: and

castItem.role: welds the data of his martyrdom into a cannonball . This man
generalizes
castItem.roleDesc: and Parbury at once perceives that husbands are not the

castItem.role: victims of special visitation
castItem.roleDesc: but of an epidemic . The thing is

castItem.role: universal . It can be classified ; it can even be attacked . He stands
shoulder to shoulder with his suffering brothers
castItem.roleDesc: and makes his stroke

castItem.role: for liberty
This is everyday life and the dialogue expresses it ; the lines are
neither too bright nor good for any drawing-room . Here are no
sky-rocketings to make the hearer gasp at the playwright 's cleverness
while at the same time they accentuate the difference between his own
world and the world as it glitters from the stage . It is the talk to
be expected out of the mouths of admirable yet matter-of-fact persons
with whom we are quite at home . This is the man you meet at any
corner
castItem.roleDesc: who is living his life as he conceives it , and is vaguely

castItem.role: discomfited when the pattern comes out wrong . He and his fellow
puppets are related in the most intimate and delightful way to our own
cousins and aunts . It is a group of sharply differentiated types :
Parbury
castItem.roleDesc: honey-combed with something that passes for amiability ; his

castItem.role: charming ruler ; worldly-wise Gunning
castItem.roleDesc: fitted like a glove with amiable

castItem.role: cynicisms ; the Colonel
castItem.roleDesc: clad in rejuvenescence like the spring ; and

castItem.role: Miss Woodward
castItem.roleDesc: an original piquing to the intelligence of any actress

castItem.role: ambitious to “ create a part . ”

The comedy made an instant and striking success
castItem.roleDesc: and ran to enormous

castItem.role: business until the end of the season . It was revived on January 29
1902 , when the press , previously unstinting in its praise , greeted it
with a renewed enthusiasm . The Times says of it
castItem.roleDesc: at this second

castItem.role: hearing : “ No English dramatist of our time has turned out more
humorous or more human work than this delightful comedy . Every feeling
in it is , as the French say , ‘ lived , ’ and every word of it tells
There is not a false note
castItem.roleDesc: no over-strained sentiment , no

castItem.role: over-emphasized phrase in it from one end to the other . Wit it has in
abundance , but not in superabundance — wit , that is , that obviously
belongs to the speaker and does not delusively suggest the author
Truth , too , it has , but always simple , straightforward , fundamental
truth
castItem.roleDesc: truth that comes home to men 's business and bosoms , not the

castItem.role: far-fetched truth which costs a headache to master it . . . . The
Comic Spirit
castItem.roleDesc: as expounded by Mr. George Meredith , inhabits it . We

castItem.role: laugh at its personages and forgive them with an intimate solace
castItem.roleDesc: for

castItem.role: in forgiving them we laughingly forgive ourselves . . . . The whole
tone of the play is quiet , it soothes , it provokes smiles , chuckles
gentle ripples of laughter . It is a rebuke
castItem.roleDesc: a kindly , playful rebuke

castItem.role: to the wild and whirling zealots of theatrical violence . We are
reminded of the praise which Matthew Arnold bestowed upon the style of
Addison — ‘ perfect , ’ he said , ‘ in measure , balance and propriety . ’ ”
Equally warm tributes to the comedy as an unusual work of dramatic art
were accorded on its presentation , September 11 , 1899 , at the Empire
Theatre

Of this performance Mr. J. Ranken Towse
castItem.roleDesc: in the New York Evening

castItem.role: Post
castItem.roleDesc: says : “ Mr. Drew played Parbury with his accustomed neatness and

castItem.role: dexterity . . . . The play
castItem.roleDesc: perhaps , may not be quite highly seasoned

castItem.role: enough with dramatic incident for the great mass of the public
castItem.roleDesc: but

castItem.role: its ingenuity
castItem.roleDesc: its simplicity , its truthfulness and its humor will

castItem.role: commend it strongly to connoisseurs . ”
It was afterwards given in the principal cities of the United States
with Mr. Drew as the victimized husband
castItem.roleDesc: and met everywhere with the

castItem.role: same enthusiastic favor . This year

Mr . Chambers 's earlier work lay more in the direction of strong dramas
such as “ Captain Swift , ” “ The Idler , ” and “ John a ’ Dreams , ” but the
comedy of these plays
castItem.roleDesc: especially the last , was of a character to

castItem.role: foreshadow to some extent the praiseworthy achievement represented by
“ The Tyranny of Tears . ”

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: SCENE .— MR . CLEMENT PARBURY 'S study at his house in the neighbourhood of Hampstead Heath . The main entrance leading from the hall is C. A door , R ., leads to the dining-room . A glass door , R. C ., opens into a garden . The fireplace is C. The room is comfortably and not severely furnished . The furniture is made up of “ odds and ends ” selected with taste . The couch down L. is a deep and cosy one ; the desk or writing-table about R. C . is a large and serviceable one . There is a smaller desk higher up , and near it on wall , R ., a telephone apparatus . The apartment altogether represents the workshop of a literary man of careless good taste . There is a touch , too , of femininity in its decorations , and a portrait of MRS. PARBURY is the only picture on the walls , which otherwise are mostly hidden by bookcases .

div.stage: For a few moments before and when the curtain rises the noise of street singers is heard . MISS WOODWARD and EVANS are discovered . MISS WOODWARD is dressed with severe simplicity in a costume of dark colour , with linen collar and cuffs ; her dark hair is drawn back from her forehead . Her costume , being well cut , does not conceal the graceful outline of her figure . She is a handsome , innocent , yet determined-looking girl of twenty . She is at the window looking out .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Raising his voice above the outside singers .They would n't listen to me , Miss Woodward !Suddenly the music stops . A pause .Ah , they 've listened to Mr. Parbury !MISS WOODWARD goes to desk , R ., sits .Mr. Parbury 's a very masterful man — outside his house — is n't he , Miss ?MISS WOODWARD favours EVANS with a cold stare , then resumes work at desk .Aside .What an iceberg that young woman is !Telephone bell rings .

div.stage: Exit EVANS , L .
MISS WOODWARD goes to telephone and takes line .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Speaking into telephone — very sweetly .Yes , are you there ?— yes — who are you ? Speak a little louder , please . Oh !— Well ? Yes — I do n't know — Mr. Parbury 's just coming in now — he 'll speak to you — keep the line .

div.stage: She returns to the desk .
Enter MR. PARBURY from garden . His hair is untidy ; he is flustered and cross . He is an agreeable-looking man of about forty .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Thank heaven , they 're gone ! This house is a mistake ! With the nerve force one expends in swearing at street singers one might do some good work . Make a note , please — look for house in secluded part of country .MISS WOODWARD makes note .And make a note — write Times re Street Music ; suggest Local Option .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: The Saturday Sentinel is waiting to speak to you on the telephone .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , worrying about the article , I suppose .Goes to telephone .Hullo ! hullo !Gives them a ring up .Are you there ?Crossly .Are you there ? Well ?Pause ; he listens .Oh , of course , still harping on my article . I suppose that 's you , Jackson ? Oh , well , if you 'll keep this confounded telephone quiet , and send a man to clear the neighbourhood of street singers , you 'll have a chance of receiving the copy in half-an-hour . What ? All right , old man . Yes , yes . I 'll send it by special messenger . Yes . Goodbye !Rings off , and hangs up tube .That is another mistake — that telephone .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I was afraid you would find it so .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You were right ! You are always right ! But my wife thought it would save me a lot of correspondence and a lot of going out .Aside , with a sigh .I always liked going out .Aloud .Make a note , please — get rid of the telephone .MISS WOODWARD makes note .Goes to top of table , R. C .Now we 'll get on , please . I 've promised the article in half-an-hour .Looks at his watch .They go to press this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Sits at desk , note-book before her .Shall I read the last sentence ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Please .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Reading .“ The pity of it is that Mr. Theodore Bellevue seems to enjoy a positively huge contentment of his own achievement —— ”

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Thinking .The pity of it — yes — yes , of his own achievement . Yes .Walks the stage .AchievementUnder his breath .Damn the street singers ! Damn the telephone !Aloud .What is it ? Oh — ah ! Contentment of his own achievement — er — er —Dictates .“ One gathers from the complacency of his manner —Pause— that his iconoclasm is its own reward — ” Er — “ What follows in the approval of the unthinking — the applause of the uncultured — ”Pause .What 's that ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: The applause of the uncultured .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: “ Makes up — makes up — ” Er —Pulls his hair .Er ——

div.stage: Enter MRS. PARBURY , L. She is a pretty , fragile , little woman of about twenty-eight , and is charmingly dressed .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm not interrupting , am I , darling ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Concealing his irritation .No , darling , but ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'll be ever so quiet .Comes to couch , sits L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , I know , dear — but , I fear — I fear you 'll be rather bored . I 'm dictating an article that must be finished this afternoon ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , I shall like it ! Go on as if I were not in the room . But oh , how tumbled your hair is .Rises , goes to him .I must put it straight . Then you 'll be able to think better . There ! Now I can see his clever forehead again !Goes to couch and sits .

div.stage: PARBURY walks up C. and back , trying to collect his thoughts ; then he looks at MRS. PARBURY with the wish in his face that she were not there ; finally he goes over to MISS WOODWARD and speaks in a lowered voice .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: At top of table , R .What was that last ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Reading in a lowered voice .“ What follows in the approval of the unthinking , the applause of the uncultured makes up . ”

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , yes . Makes up !Fidgeting .Makes up —Vaguely .What does it make up ? I 'm damned if I know what it does make up now ? I 've forgotten .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Looking up at him with discreet sympathy after a glance at MRS. PARBURY .Shall I go back a little ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Please do . Cut the other ; it does n't make up anything .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Reading .“ One gathers from the complacency of his manner that his iconoclasm is its own reward . ”

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Thanks . Where 's his article ?

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD rises , gives him an open magazine , and resumes her seat .
After glancing at the magazine , and still in a low voice . ] “ His smug self-sufficiency —— ” [ Pause .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Darling ! I can n't hear you .

div.stage: Pause . PARBURY 'S and MISS WOODWARD 'S eyes meet .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Ca n't you , dear ? I suppose I must unconsciously have lowered my voice .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm sure you did .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 've an idea .Comes behind her and touches her shoulders caressingly .Suppose I finish the article quickly and give it to you to read before sending it away ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , do .

div.stage: PARBURY looks at her , expecting her to move , but she does n't .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Wonderingly .Well ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You — you 're not going ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Going !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , dear . I thought ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: With great reproach , and looking as if about to cry .Clement !She rises , and with trembling hands begins to gather up her fancy work .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Relenting .Do n't go , dear , unless you wish to .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: More tremblingly and tearfully .I certainly do n't wish to remain where I am unwelcome .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Reproachfully .Mabel !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I thought I had a right to be where my husband was — that the privileges of a wife were at least equal to those of a secretary .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: In a low voice .Hush , dear !Turns to MISS WOODWARD , who has been a secret but attentive observer of the scene .Miss Woodward , would you kindly run what we have done into type ? We 'll finish presently .

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD rises , takes her notes , and crosses to door , L. At the screen she pauses a moment , shrugs her shoulders , and exits R. I. E .
PARBURY passes his arm round MRS. PARBURY .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Freeing herself .Oh , no ; you wished me to go , and I 'm going .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: It does n't matter now .Grimly .The article has n't a million to one chance of being finished this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Why did you send Miss Woodward away ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Frankly ?

div.stage: Puts magazine on table , R .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Because I hate scenes before other people .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Scenes ! What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: C .What ! Is n't there to be a scene ? How splendid !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: L. C .I do n't understand the humour you are in .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm in a capital humour , dear . You 've saved me for the moment from a savage attack on the work of a man whom I respect and admire .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You mean simply that I 've interrupted your work . You will not have reason to complain again .

div.stage: Is going .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Wait , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: No , no . There are things one can n't get over . Perhaps you can explain why it is that Miss Woodward 's presence does n't disturb you , while mine does ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Easily . Miss Woodward is a mouse .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I hate mice !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I mean she is a table — a chair — a desk — a dictionary — a something useful that is always in the right place at the right moment , and yet of whose presence one is pleasantly unconscious . She is a triumph of the negative .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: And I ?

div.stage: Her face is not turned to him .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Positive , my love — quite positive ; you bristle with emotions . When you are in the room , one knows it .MRS. PARBURY takes out her handkerchief and begins to cry . Pause . PARBURY , who has gone to desk , looks round inquiringly , then comes down gently and sees what she is doing .Aside .Exactly !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Wiping her eyes .Of course I quite understand now that you do n't love me .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Comes to her , concealing his impatience .But I do ! I do !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh no , you do n't ! When we were first married you did n't object to my being in the room when you were working .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I admit I did n't say so then ; I was younger , and had more patience and stronger nerves .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Turning to him with a gleam of anger .Then you admit you have always objected to my presence in your study ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Smoothly .I admit I have always felt that a writing man 's writing hours are sacred hours .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: They should n't be sacred from his wife .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Gently .They should be sacred to his wife , dear .Slight pause .If you were a writing woman you would understand what I mean .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm sure I 'm very sorry I 'm not a genius , but you understood that when you married me , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , darling , I quite understood that !He appears to say this quite unconsciously . MRS. PARBURY turns to him deeply offended , then suddenly goes up to leave the room . He quickly meets her , C .Taking her hands .I only knew you were the best little woman in the world !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Struggling to free her hands .Do n't , please . I 'm going !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: To send Miss Woodward to you , since you prefer her society to mine .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: But I tell you I 'm scarcely conscious of the girl 's existence ; anyway , it was you who brought her here . You may remember I proposed having a male secretary .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Yes ; to make a companion of at my expense . You were always a man 's man ! If I had had more experience I would have known that by the host of men friends you had when we married .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Cheerily .I have n't them now , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You mean — that I —Struggling to release her hands .You are most brutal . Let me go !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Not while you are angry , dear .

div.stage: Gently forces her into a chair , R. C .
There is another slight pause . She is certainly angry , but she does n't attempt to leave the chair . He looks down at her , and lays a hand lightly on her hair .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Brushing his hand away .Please do n't do that . I am not a child !PARBURY takes a chair and sits next to her . Pause .Perhaps you will tell me why you have used your superior strength to keep me here against my will ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Taking her hand .Do you know that I 'm very much in love with you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You in love with me ! You do n't know what love is ! All you feel at this moment is the sort of insolent pity the strong have for the weak .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You weak , darling ! Oh , come ! You know better than that ! You can n't be unconscious of your power !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I really do n't understand you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I only meant to remind you that after all you do always get your own way . I 'm really very glad , for I 'm sure your way must always be the best way . Oh , the power and determination of this little hand !Holding her hand .Do let me , with the deepest submission , kiss “ The Mailed Fist . ”

div.stage: He kisses her hand .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: As it pleases you to be rude to me I shall try to bear it patiently .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I do n't mean to be rude . It 's my unfortunate way of putting things . I kissed your hand because of the real tender love my heart holds for you , and for the same reason I put back this dear , rebellious little lock of hair which has escaped from over your ear . And what a perfect ear ! It 's as delicate and fragile as a shell , and it 's just the daintiest pink possible .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Mollified .I know my ears are all right , though I think you are making fun of me .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I think I 'm making love to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Suddenly taking one of his hands in hers .Oh , if you only loved me in the way I love you !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I love you in a most excellent way .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: But it 's different — you do n't understand . I love to breathe the air you breathe , to hear your voice even when it 's dictating a dry article , to listen to your footsteps , to watch the changing expressions on your face . I live by the warmth your life gives me ; you do n't grudge me that , do you ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Why , of course not , darling !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I love this room because it is yours , the surroundings are yours , the atmosphere is yours . When you are out ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Gently patting her hand .Which is not often , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: When you are out I always stay here , because here I get most of you ; even the thin odour of cigarette smoke is dear to me . Smoke now .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Shall I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Gives him a cigarette from his case on table , and lights it .That 's delightful !Sniffs the smoke .But only because it 's you ! I used to detest tobacco .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Smiling .You dear !

div.stage: Puts his arm around her .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You understand a little now , do n't you ?

div.stage: Putting her head on his shoulder .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Perfectly !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Rising .And you are not angry any more ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Was I angry ?

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Horribly !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Not vexed about the article ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Bother the article . I knew it had n't a million to one chance !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: And it does n't matter ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Not in the least !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Then we may have tea in here ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Rather ! Let 's go the pace .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Goes to him , standing before him , her hands by her sides .Kiss me !He kisses her . She throws her arms round him and whispers to him . He whispers a word in reply . They both laugh slightly , and he playfully pinches her cheek .Brute !She smooths her hair and goes to door , L .; turns at door and blows him a kiss , to which he responds .

div.stage: Exit MRS. PARBURY , L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Standing for moment , C ., a whimsical look on his face .Dear little woman ! What a pity she cries so much !Puts chair up , R .; goes to desk and turns over pages of magazine , still continuing his thought .What a pity ! What a pity ! Enter MISS WOODWARD carrying loose type-written MS. PARBURY glances up from his magazine as she places the leaves on the desk . Oh , thanks !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Do you wish to finish the article now ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Impossible ! Tea will be taken here in a few minutes .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: With a touch of indignant surprise .Here ? . . . Oh , I beg your pardon !

lg.l: Not at all ! I said here !
lg.stage: Throws down magazine , goes up to fireplace , C. MISS WOODWARD permits a slight groan to escape her .
lg.l: Eh ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Nothing , I did n't speak !

div.stage: Sits and bends over desk .
PARBURY looks at her suddenly and keenly as though he had never noticed her before . Slight pause . She arranges papers at desk . He is leaning against the mantelpiece .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Do you know , Miss Woodward , I believe you are more disappointed about that article than I am .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I was certainly very interested .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: It was so strong ! I admire strength .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Smiling .You are not then quite the machine one gets into the habit of imagining one 's secretary to be ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Meeting his eye calmly and fearlessly for a moment .I should like to be what you wish me to be .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: A little disconcerted .Humph !Stands with his hands in his pockets looking at her , while she is busy at the desk .

div.stage: The door , L ., suddenly opens . PARBURY starts almost violently . MRS. PARBURY puts her head into the room .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Darling , I 've got rid of a would-be intruder for you . I thought you 'd like to know .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Thank you , dear ; who was it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: A horrid person named Gunning . There 's the creature 's card .Throws card into room on to chair by door L .I knew you 'd be pleased , darling ! Tea in five minutes .

div.stage: Exit MRS. PARBURY , closing door .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Gunning ! Not George surely ?Quickly gets the card .It is ! My dear old friend ; I would n't miss seeing him for worlds !Rushes to window , opens it , and bends out .Why , there he is , going across the lawn !Shouts .George ! George !! Hi ! Gunning !! !

div.stage: Runs off , R .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Outside , very distant .Hullo , Clement !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Outside .Wait a moment , old chap !

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD goes up and looks through window , comes down , and with her handkerchief carefully dusts a photograph of PARBURY which stands on book-case up L. C ., then looks at the portrait of MRS. PARBURY , which is C. on wall over mantel , shrugs her shoulders slightly , returns to desk .
Enter PARBURY and GUNNING , R ., through window .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: C ., speaking as they enter .Quite a mistake ! I assure you , my dear fellow , my wife gave orders that I was not to be disturbed , thinking I was engaged upon an important piece of work .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Looking at MISS WOODWARD .Wo n't you present me to Mrs .——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Hastily .To Miss Woodward , my secretary — certainly ! Mr. Gunning , Miss Woodward .They bow . MISS WOODWARD moves to go .Do n't go , Miss Woodward .Crosses to top of table , R. C . GUNNING puts his hat and gloves on chair , L .You might very kindly get rid of some of this correspondence for me .Takes a bundle of letters from desk .“ Dear Sir ,— I would esteem it a great favour if you would send me your photograph , together with your autograph . ”Throws letter aside , and reads another .“ My dear Sir ,— I have read with the deepest interest and the highest pleasure your deservedly successful novel , ‘ The Overthrow of Harvey Masterton , ’ and feel convinced that if you knew the story of my life —— ”Repeats business .No one can deal with these people like Miss Woodward .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Taking off his gloves .What is your method , Miss Woodward ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: It is Mr. Parbury 's — perfect civility , consistent with finality .

div.stage: Sits at desk and writes letters .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Excellent !Sits and addresses PARBURY .I suppose being a popular author entails a lot of correspondence ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Awful !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: L. C .For my part , my correspondence is practically nil .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I have noticed it with pain .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , I 'd have written to you , but what was the good of it ? I 'm not literary , and I 'm not married .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: And so you 've kept away for five years .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: About that .

div.stage: Sits on arm of sofa , L. C .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Five years and three months — for I 've been married all that time , and you neither came to the wedding nor called on me afterwards .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I was discreet .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Discreet ! Damned unfriendly , I call it , considering the years we had been pals .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Well , the rest of our old set stuck to you , anyway . What has become of them ? Take Wybrow , for instance — an awful good chap !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Wybrow , Wybrow — what has become of Wybrow ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Never comes here , eh ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , he did a few times some years ago , but ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I understand — a little too Bohemian .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quickly .Not for me , George , I assure you .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No , no , of course not , my dear chap . Exit Bohemian Wybrow . Then there was Carson — one of the best ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Warmly .Was n't he a good fellow ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Capital ! Where is he ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Married , you know .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: So I heard . You meet constantly , of course ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No , we met them at Brighton one winter some years ago , but I do n't think our wives quite — you understand , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes , yes , I understand . You dropped the Carsons . But Burleigh ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Burleigh — ah !

div.stage: Laughs .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: There was a great spirit if you like ; he was your best man .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes ; he gave me this watch .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Which you still wear . Touching constancy ! When did you see him last ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Wait a moment . What is all this interrogation for ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Idle curiosity if you like — study of life if you like . Come , out with it , when did you last have dear old Tom Burleigh to dinner ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Almost defiantly .The day we returned from our honeymoon .

div.stage: Slightly awkward pause .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Musingly .About five years and six weeks ago .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Of course , I see a lot of him at the Clubs . That is to say , I used to when I was still a Club man .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Which now you are not ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Which now I am not ! What does a man want with a Club when he has a home of his own ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Excellent sentiment ; but neither the sentiment nor the words are your own , Clement .Their eyes meet and they burst into laughter .I know , I know ; “ and what does a man want with men friends when he has a wife of his own , ” and “ the husband 's old friends are the wife 's worst enemies , ” and “ what I say about Clubs is , down with them ! ”

div.stage: Laughs , sits on sofa , L. C .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Suddenly serious .What the devil are you laughing at , George ? You do n't presume ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I — why , of course not , my dear chap . Only now you see how wise I was not to intrude after your marriage , not to wait for my conge as the other poor boys did ! I knew something .

lg.l: You always did , you brute ! I believe you were born knowing something .
But seriously
, George ,
I assure you she 's the best little woman in the world !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Why , of course ; it would be impious to suggest otherwise .

div.stage: Exit MISS WOODWARD .
His eyes follow her off . ] A perfect wife , and a charming secretary ! You 're a lucky fellow , Clement !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Is Miss Woodward charming ? On my word , I had n't noticed it , but I 'm in love with my wife , you see .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Of course you would be the last to discover that your secretary was personally pleasing .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You 're a sinister scoundrel , George , and coarse to a fault . Now , tell me what you 've been doing all these years — shedding your illusions apparently .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 've had none to lose since I grew up . I got rid of mine about the time of measles and whooping-cough .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: It 's a pity .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Not at all . One can n't attain the proper philosophical attitude towards life while one nourishes illusions ; one can never gain perspective .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Great man ! How beautifully you talk ! I suppose you have quite a nice thing in perspectives about with you now .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Pretty well .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: So much for the journey of the soul . What of the body ? Where have you been ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Round the world twice since I saw you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What did you see on the other side ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Just what one sees on this side ; there is always a man — and a woman .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I know you were adventuring in Upper India last year , for the papers were full of a rather fine thing you did — saved a lot of miserable lives — an ordinary , manly , commonplace , heroic , English sort of thing .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , do n't mention that ; one was carried away by impulse .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: And so we keep our impulses even when we lose our illusions ; I 'm glad of that anyway .Then he comes behind GUNNING 'S chair , takes him by the shoulder , and shakes him .Old fool ! I can n't help liking you as much as ever !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Looking up with genuine pleasure .Really ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Honestly !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Rises , puts his hands on PARBURY 'S shoulders .Well , I 'm glad , because I 've often been weak enough to regret not seeing you . As for your literary successes , I suppose I ought to congratulate you ; but I always knew you 'd be a great man , because you never bored me .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Drily .Thanks so much . Now tell me how you found me .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: By means of the illustrated press — interview with Mr. Clement Parbury — copyright . The author of the “ Overthrow of Harvey something ” at his pretty retreat at Hampstead — copyright . Snapshot of Mr. Parbury at work — copyright . View of the study from the garden — view of the garden from the study — copyright .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Shut up ! You make me blush .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Forgive me — it 's only envy . It 's the envious people who call this a vulgar age , I suppose .

div.stage: Enter SERVANT , L ., places occasional table for tea in front of sofa , L. C ., and exits L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Now you are to see my wife . How do you imagine her ? Large , I suppose , with huge hands and feet and a beetling brow ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm content to wait . Re-enter SERVANT , L ., with tea service .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: When you have had tea , you will go away to dress . You will return here to dinner at eight .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I think not .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: One moment . You will probably meet only my wife 's father , Colonel Armitage , and your dinner will be a fairly plain one , but I promise that your palate will not be outraged .

lg.l: I really think not , old man . I remember the fate of old Burleigh . And
I never even gave you a watch .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: George , you hurt me .Slight pause .Then you refuse ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I make conditions .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What are they ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That you come yachting with me from to-morrow till the end of the week . I 've hired a charming little twenty-tonner , one after your own heart — that is , if your heart or my memory has n't entirely changed .

lg.l: Splendid ! There 's nothing I should like so much ; and
I 've no special work on hand just now .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Then it 's agreed ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Certainly !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Good ; we 'll drink of the Cuvee 36 , brush up our swearing vocabulary , and I 'll teach you to gain perspective !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: His face suddenly falling .Oh , the deuce !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: What 's the matter ? What are you afraid of ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Of nothing in the world !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Slapping him on the back .Hero !

div.stage: Enter MRS. PARBURY , L ., wearing a bright smile , which fades when she sees GUNNING .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Mabel , I want to present you to my dear old friend , George Gunning . My wife , George .

div.stage: GUNNING crosses to MRS. PARBURY . Shakes hands .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: How do you do ? I 'm very pleased .

div.stage: She gives him simultaneously a cold smile and a stiff handshake .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm very delighted to meet Clement 's wife .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You 'll let me give you some tea ?

div.stage: Goes to tea-table ; sits on sofa .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Thank you .Aside to PARBURY .She 's charming !

div.stage: PARBURY digs him in the ribs . GUNNING goes to tea-table . PARBURY sits at desk .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Handing GUNNING tea-cup .I 've given you no sugar .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'll take one piece .

div.stage: Does so .
Enter MISS WOODWARD , R. I. E ., with MS ., which she hands to PARBURY .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: He reads and signs letters .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Clement , come for your tea .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: In one moment , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Miss Woodward , you will take tea ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Thank you , yes .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: To MRS. PARBURY .Allow me .

div.stage: Takes MISS WOODWARD 'S cup to her , and offers her bread and butter , & c .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You 've often heard me speak of Gunning , Mabel ; we were at Cambridge together .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh yes , I remember !To GUNNING .You were very great friends ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Inseparables !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I should say so !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Uneasily .Indeed !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Comes over and takes his tea .You see , Gunning had been my fag at Harrow , and my ill-treatment of him inspired a dog-like devotion .To MISS WOODWARD .Let me take your cup .Adds in a lower voice .I 've an idea !

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD goes to desk ; PARBURY follows her to desk .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Let me .

div.stage: Assists MRS. PARBURY with the tea service .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: To MISS WOODWARD in a low voice .I think I can finish the article in three sentences . Take your notes into the other room ; I 'll join you in a moment .

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD gathers her notes and exits R .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Pouring out a fresh cup of tea for GUNNING .But of course it 's not in the nature of things that college friendships , however strong , can last always . Time estranges , does n't it , Mr. Gunning , and fate drives people into different — well , different ways of life , does n't it ? Some men marry soon . Are you married , Mr. Gunning ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Alas , no , Mrs. Parbury !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: He has too much respect for your sex , dear . Forgive me for three minutes .

div.stage: Exit PARBURY , R .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Not married ! Well , I should have thought ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That I 'm old enough to know better . I admit it .

div.stage: Sits R. C .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well , I was going to say that in marriage a man changes so much . He becomes more — more ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Gently .Respectable ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well , I was n't going to say quite that ; though , as you suggest it , no doubt it is true . I was going to say more responsible . He enters into a broader , a fuller life ; he gains in nobility , do n't you think ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Amused .Oh , no doubt Clement has improved enormously !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm so glad you recognise that . You may smoke , Mr. Gunning , if you care to .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Thank you . I 'll steal one of Clement 's cigarettes if I may ?

div.stage: Takes cigarette from box on desk .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of course Clement was always good and strong and clever . It only wanted marriage to — to ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: To perfect him !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well , I was going to say to complete him ; but it comes to the same thing , does n't it ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Quite , quite !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I found my happiness when I married Clement .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You had been looking for it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of course ; is n't that every woman 's duty ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes , yes ; and every man 's ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Less confidently .Well , yes , I should think so .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: And one 's happiness once found is worth fighting for ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Firmly .Worth fighting very hard for !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Drily .Of course .Aside .Poor Burleigh !

div.stage: Lights cigarette .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You , I suppose , have never met a woman who could make you happy ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I have never met a woman whom I was sure of being able to make happy .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Slightly embarrassed .Oh !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: And , anyway , the state of marriage has always appeared to me to be a state of warfare .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Mr. Gunning , you little know ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I admit the case of you and Clement to be an exceptional one . I 'm talking of ordinary cases — the average marriage ; there you will find , according to my observation , an endless war — a war of self-interests , a war of opposing emotions , a war of irreconcilable nervous organisations ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Gunning !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Viewed from the hill-tops rather a pitiful sort of war , in which can be won neither the full joys of love nor the complete glories of battle .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Gunning !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I remain single , Mrs. Parbury , quite without happiness — except in the reflection that I am neither an oppressor exercising a daily tyranny , nor a slave rightly struggling to be free .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of course I do n't in the least agree with you .The telephone bell rings .Rising .There 's some one on the telephone — forgive me .Goes to telephone box and puts the communicator to her ear .Are you there ?— yes — who are you ?— the article — yes — no , you can n't have it to-day — no , it has n't a million to one chance of being finished .To GUNNING , with a smile .That 's Clement 's slang , not mine .Again into telephone .What ? Enter PARBURY and MISS WOODWARD , R . I say it has n't a million to one chance of being finished .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What ? Who is it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: It 's the Saturday Sentinel .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: But , my dear , the article is finished .Rushes to telephone .MISS WOODWARD and GUNNING are laughing secretly . MRS. PARBURY stands C ., rather confused .At telephone .Hullo ! Hullo ! Are you there ?Rings violently .Hullo — oh ! is that you , Jackson ? . . . what 's the matter ?Rather a long pause . He smiles while listening .No , no , not at all , my dear chap . What was said was , ‘ It 's a million to one you 'll have the copy in half-an-hour ’ — eh ?— yes , those were the very words . . . no , quite a mistake , you do n't listen properly . A messenger has just gone off in a cab with it . What ? Yes .Laughs .All right ! Good-bye !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Seeing MISS WOODWARD laughing .I really do n't know what there is to laugh at , Miss Woodward .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I was only smiling at the messenger in the cab .

div.stage: Folds MS. and puts it in envelope .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , send some one at once , please , Miss Woodward .

div.stage: Exit MISS WOODWARD , R. V. E .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: It was n't my fault , dear . You know you did use those words .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: My fault entirely .Aside to GUNNING .Have you told her ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: About the yachting ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Why , of course not . That 's your affair , my dear fellow .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: His hand on GUNNING 'S shoulder .Mabel , dear , we 're going yachting for a few days . I think I want a little change .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Coming towards them , brightly .Oh , what a good idea ! When do we go ?PARBURY and GUNNING look at each other .Are you coming , Mr. Gunning ?

div.stage: PARBURY presses GUNNING forward . GUNNING looks round at PARBURY reproachfully . PARBURY goes up stage .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Embarrassed .Well , it 's my yacht , Mrs. Parbury , but she 's very small — only a little tub of a thing ; and —Looks at his watch .By Jove ! I 'll never be able to dress and get back for dinner if I do n't hurry .Gets his hat and gloves , L. Goes up quickly .I need only say au revoir ; do n't trouble , Clement , I 'll find my way out — au revoir !

div.stage: Exit GUNNING , L .
MRS. PARBURY , who is puzzled , sits on sofa .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Calling after GUNNING .Dinner at eight , remember .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Outside .All right !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Shuts the door .Capital fellow , George Gunning !

div.stage: Comes to back of sofa .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: What does he mean by a little tub of a thing ? Surely we 're not ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No , dear , certainly not . You 're quite right . I would n't think of letting you run any risks .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Then we 're not going ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No , dear ; that is to say , Gunning and I are going .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Rising , aghast .Without me ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Only for a few days , of course .

div.stage: Laughing feebly .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You are not serious ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quite !

div.stage: His laugh becomes feebler .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: But — but you never go away without me !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I have n't hitherto , but ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well ?

div.stage: Appears about to cry .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 've been working very hard , you know , lately . I feel I want a change .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Tearfully .It does n't occur to you that I might want a change .

lg.l: Well , have one , dear . Aunt Martha would be delighted to have you at
Oaklands .
I do n't want to go to Aunt Martha . How would you like to go to Aunt
Martha ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Suppressing a groan .What is it you do want ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Quickly .You ! I want to be with you ! It 's very simple — it 's not asking very much . If you do n't like my being with you , why did you marry me ?

div.stage: Taking out her handkerchief .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Now , dear , please do n't cry !Aside .If she does , I 'm done for !Aloud .It 's only common sense that you can n't go knocking about with a couple of men in a tub of a boat .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of course I quite know now that you do n't love me .

div.stage: Bursts into tears . Sits on sofa .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: With real irritation .Oh , damn it !Goes up , but turns quickly and comes down to her .‘ Pon my soul , you make me almost hate ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of course you hate me . Your old friend has done that for me . You are breaking my heart !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Who has recovered control of his temper and resumed his natural bantering tone .Not at all , dear .Sits at his desk and affects to be busy .I was only going to say that I hated — now , what the deuce was it I hated ?— oh , I know — to see a woman cry . I do think a woman is wise who does her crying in private , and yet — I wonder — they know best — millions to one they know best . I must write something about it .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Rises , goes to top of table , R. She is wiping her eyes , her back to him .Of course , you 're going all the same ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Affecting great pre-occupation .Going ? Going where ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: With Mr. Gunning .

div.stage: Pause . She continues to cry gently .

lg.l: Gunning — Gunning !— who 's Gunning ? Oh — George — yachting , you mean ! Not
I ! I 'm staying here .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Comes towards him gladly , her arms extended .Clement !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Eh ? Oh , forgive me for a few minutes .

div.stage: Writes .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Reproachfully .I was only going to kiss you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Writing .All right , dear — presently — presently , there 's a dear girl !MRS. PARBURY has a slow silent exit , looking back at him .He does n't look up , but goes on writing . When the door closes , he puts down his pen .Oh , the tyranny of it ! The tyranny of it !

div.stage: Slow Curtain .
END OF ACT I .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: SCENE .— The same as Act I . Evening after dinner the same day . The room is lighted with lamps , but as it is a still warm evening , the curtains are not drawn over the glass door which leads into the garden and is open .

div.stage: Enter EVANS , L. He places cigars and cigarettes on occasional table , and lights a small spirit cigar-lamp . [ Exit . ] Voices of ladies and a ripple of laughter heard from the drawing-room , and for a moment the sound made by fingers running lightly and irresponsibly over the keys of the piano . Enter COLONEL ARMITAGE , followed by GUNNING and PARBURY . ARMITAGE goes to mantelpiece . GUNNING selects the easiest chair in the room . PARBURY goes to occasional table . ARMITAGE is a well-preserved man of sixty-five , very carefully dressed — something of an elderly dandy .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Cigarette or cigar , George ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Thanks , I have a cigarette .

div.stage: Takes one from his case and lights it .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Colonel ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Thank you , I 'll take a cigar . I think , however , I 'll — er — smoke it in the garden . Mabel 's limited appreciation of tobacco ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , Mabel wo n't mind — she 's quite educated .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Not beyond the cigarette , I fancy .

div.stage: He strolls to the glass door , lights his cigar , and steps out . For a few moments he is still seen , then he wanders away .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Nice old chap , your father-in-law .

lg.l: Is n't he ? I 'm quite fond of him .
lg.stage: Pause . They smoke in silence , PARBURY standing at mantelpiece .
lg.l: What are you thinking of ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm not thinking . I 'm digesting . I had an excellent dinner .

div.stage: Enter EVANS with coffee , & c. GUNNING takes coffee .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Cognac , sir , or green chartreuse ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Cognac .He takes glass .Thank you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Colonel , here 's your coffee .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Outside .I 'll have it out here , if I may .

div.stage: PARBURY takes his coffee and liqueur .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Serve Colonel Armitage 's coffee in the garden .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: Exit EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 've wired for the champagne .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Uneasily .Oh , yes !

div.stage: Slight pause .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I notice the glass keeps up well .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Really ? Good !

div.stage: Slight pause .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes , we ought to have capital weather .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Capital !He is very embarrassed .If it does n't rain it 'll be pretty — er — fine .

div.stage: Drinks . Puts his cup on mantelpiece .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Favours him with a slow stare .What 's the matter , old man ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Nothing in the world . Why ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , it does n't matter . But I think the change will do you good .Slight pause .By the way , would to-morrow afternoon suit you for a start ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Standing with his back to the fireplace , looking up at the ceiling .I 'm not going , old man .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Indifferently .Oh ! Re-enter EVANS , R ., from garden , and exit L. Silence till he has gone .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , you do n't seem surprised .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Effecting a yawn .I never permit myself to be surprised .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Or disappointed .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh yes , I own I 'm disappointed . I looked for a good time for a few days . You were the only one of the old lot available , and you were the best of them . I can n't bear the new lot . They wear strange colours , drop their “ g 's , ” and get on one 's nerves .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm really sorry , George .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do n't bother . One simply goes alone .Discreetly .The calls of business are often irresistible .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Do n't rot . You know what the situation is .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Mine is one of those poor intelligences that never know without information .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'll supply it .

div.stage: Sits on arm of chair , R. C .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do n't , if it matters .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I will , though it does matter .Grimly .My wife wept .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Unanswerable argument .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quite . George , what the devil is a man to do ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I knew a man who once interfered between a husband and wife who were disagreeing . The husband and wife each got a black eye . The man got two .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You might at least talk .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , certainly .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You know the situation .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Well , if one dare say so , I fancy you are suffering from the tyranny of a fascinating egoism .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm suffering from the tyranny of tears .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: What I can n't understand is how a man of your strong nature arrived where you are .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'll make an effort to tell you . To begin with , I suppose I 'm fairly good-natured .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh yes !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Or say , if you like , of indolent habit , which after all often passes for the same thing . Then of course I was in love — I am still . One drifted . It 's so easy to give way in little things — really not unpleasant when you 're in love . And then there 's one 's work , which fills the mind and makes the little things appear smaller than they are . I say one drifted .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Sometimes , if I know you , you rebelled . What then ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Promptly .Tears ! And over such absurdly paltry things ! Oh , the farcical tragedy of it all ! I wished to go shooting for a few days . Tears ! I fancied dining and spending the evening with an old chum . Tears ! I would go on a walking tour for a week . Tears ! Some one would ask me for three days ’ hunting . Tears ! Tears , you understand , always on hand . Tears — tears — tears ad ——Pulling himself up .No .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Quietly .No — not ad nauseam .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No , that would be too low a thing to say .

div.stage: Goes up R. C . Takes stopper out of the decanter .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do you know , Clement , I really like you tremendously .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Thanks , old man . Have some more brandy ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No thanks .Pause .Do n't stop . I 'm interested .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: That 's all . I drifted , almost unconsciously , right up to to-day , for all the world like the man in the moral story-book one read as a child on Sundays , who drifted in his boat on the Erie River towards Niagara . To-night I 'm conscious — I 'm awake — I can feel the water gliding along the boat 's keel . I can see Niagara . I do n't like it . What the devil 's one to do ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Get out and walk .

div.stage: Pause . They smoke .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Of course , I shall change it all . I must , but it will be beastly work .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Beastly . When do you begin ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: When occasion serves . I can n't go back over this yachting business . I 've said I 'm not going .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Quite right .

div.stage: Slight pause .

lg.l: Oh , if the exigeant women only knew — if they only knew !
Enter COLONEL ARMITAGE , R .
Talking of brandies , this is Hennessy ‘ 63 . Have some , Colonel ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Perhaps half a glass .

div.stage: Takes brandy and sits .
Enter MRS. PARBURY , L ., from drawing-room .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Miss Woodward and I are boring each other . Shall we come to you , or will you come to us ?GUNNING and ARMITAGE rise .There , the question 's answered .

div.stage: Sits on sofa , L .
Enter MISS WOODWARD , L. She goes to the desk .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: To MRS. PARBURY .You were playing the piano just now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , but I play wretchedly nowadays . I gave up practising when we married .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: One should never give up an accomplishment .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: You used to play charmingly , Mabel .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You thought so , dear , and that was enough for me .She rises and crosses to C .Why do n't we sit in the garden ? It 's a perfect night .COLONEL strolls off to garden .MRS. PARBURY goes to PARBURY , who is standing by fireplace , and takes his arm . In a low voice .Are you still angry ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: As they go out to the garden .I angry with you ! Nonsense .He pats her hand .Poor little woman ! Poor little woman !

div.stage: Exit MR. and MRS. PARBURY .

lg.stage: Crossing to R. C . top of the table .
lg.l: Are you not coming , Miss
Woodward ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: No , thank you . I have some work to do .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: But you seem to me to be always working .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I need n't , you know . I do it because I like it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: What are you doing now ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Correcting proof sheets of a new novel . It will save Mr. Parbury the trouble of doing it to-morrow .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I wanted you to talk to me .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yourself .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm not interesting .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: On the contrary .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: What do you wish to know ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: All about you . May I ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Will you go away and leave me to work if I tell you ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Comes down by chair R. C .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Putting down her pen , and resting her cheek on her hand .I 'm the thirteenth daughter of a parson . Why my parents had thirteen daughters , I do n't know ; but I suppose it was because they are very poor . We were all given the names of flowers — Rose , Lily , Tulip , Mignonette — I can n't remember them all — but Hyacinth fell to my lot . Why we were called after flowers , I do n't know ; but I suppose it was because we are none of us the least like flowers . My eldest sister married my father 's curate . I do n't know why , but I suppose it was because she came first and is the plainest in the family .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Laughing .Yes , well ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Speaking in an even , emotionless way .Two other of my sisters run a Kindergarten , and one other is a governess . Personally I would rather be a domestic servant . The others remain at home , help in the house , and await husbands . I fear they will wait in vain , because there are so many women in our part of the country and so few men . For my part I seized an early opportunity of learning shorthand and typewriting — and — well , here I am . Now you know the story of my life .

div.stage: She returns to her work .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm afraid it was deuced impertinent of me to ask .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Not at all — only eminently man-like .

div.stage: Pause . She works , he smokes .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: And so you have found your happiness .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Oh no . I 've only just started to look for it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh ho ! Ambitious !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Very . Have you ever been poor ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes , at one time — had to pawn things .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I mean being one of fifteen in family — large inferior joints to last for days — hot , cold , hashed , minced , shepherd 's pie —GUNNING shudders at this— too much potatoes — too much boiled rice — too much bread and dripping — too much weak tea — too much polishing up of things not worth polishing up — too much darning on too little material — and for ever giving thanks out of all proportion to the benefits received . I wish some one would write the history of a hat or a frock — I mean a hat or a frock that has marched steadily and sullenly under various guises through an entire family such as ours , from the mother down to the youngest girl . What might be written of the thoughts that had been thought under such a hat , or of the hearts that had felt under such a frock !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Why do n't you write the story ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Perhaps some day I shall try .Returns to her work .In the meantime you ought to go . You promised , you know . You have nothing more to learn . I do n't think in all my life I 've talked so much about myself as I have to you , a stranger .

div.stage: She keeps her eyes on her work .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You have been engagingly frank . I do hope I shall have another opportunity ——

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Not at all likely , Mr. Gunning .Pause .Goodnight .Still without looking up .

div.stage: GUNNING looks at her , goes up to the window , turns , looks at her again .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: At window .Good-night , Miss Woodward .

div.stage: Exit to garden , R .
MISS WOODWARD goes on with her work for a few moments , then drops her face on her hand in her favourite attitude .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Soliloquising .Rather than go back , I — well , I know I 'd rather die .She looks over the pages for a moment or two , then yawns slightly ; she gathers her pages together and places a paperweight over them .That will have to do .She rises , looks off R .There was actually a man ready to take a sort of languid interest in me . Quite a new experience .She takes up PARBURY 'S photograph and speaks to it .You do n't take an interest in me of any kind , do you ?To the photograph .You never will , and I do n't think I want you to . But I do want to stay near you , because you are so strong — Enter MRS. PARBURY from garden carrying the COLONEL 'S coffee cup and saucer . — and so weak , and so kind , and so foolish .

div.stage: MRS. PARBURY has come down and is watching her unobserved . MISS WOODWARD slowly raises the photograph to her lips . The cup and saucer drop from MRS. PARBURY 'S hand to the floor and are broken . MISS WOODWARD , much startled , slowly turns towards MRS. PARBURY , and their eyes meet . There is a pause . Suddenly , with a quick movement , MRS. PARBURY snatches the photograph from MISS WOODWARD .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: How dare you ! How dare you !Long pause . She is almost breathless . Then she partly regains self-control .What train do you intend taking ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: R. C .I do n't understand you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I mean for your home , of course .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Moves as if she had received a blow , and clasps her hands together .I am not going home .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , indeed you are . You do n't suppose you can stay here , do you ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Why should n't I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: How dare you ask that when I have just caught you in the act of kissing my husband 's photograph ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: That was in a moment of abstraction . I was n't even thinking of Mr. Parbury .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh ! And you are the daughter of a clergyman !She goes up and fetches the A. B. C . from bookcase , and offers it to MISS WOODWARD .Here is the A. B. C .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Turning away .I have no use for it just now , thank you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Then I 'll look you out an early morning train myself .Sits L .Let me see —turning over leaves— Carfields , Worcestershire , is n't it ? Here it is . 7. 20 . I suppose that 's too early . 9. 35 ; that will do . Please understand you are to take the 9. 35 from Paddington in the morning .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Firmly .I shall do nothing of the kind .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Ignoring the remark .In the meanwhile there is no necessity that my husband should know the reason of your going . You can make some excuse . I would n't have him know for worlds .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Of course he shall never know from me — but I want you to quite understand , Mrs. Parbury , that I am not going to Carfields to-morrow . Rather than go home under the circumstances I would starve in the gutter .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well , you must find a lodging till you get other employment . You will have a month 's salary , of course . Anyway , I 'm determined you leave this house in the morning .

div.stage: Goes up C. Puts A. B. C . on chair up L. C .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Is there any real occasion for my leaving ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Have n't you sufficient delicacy of feeling left to teach you that ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Warmly .I do n't think I need lessons of delicacy of feeling from you .Slight pause .I 'm sorry I said that , and it means a great deal for me to say I 'm sorry . I 'm sorry too about the photograph . I think it all might be forgotten .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Forgotten !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: After all , I 'm only a girl ; and I 've worked very hard for Mr. Parbury . I think you might be more lenient .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: At fireplace .I 'm very sorry for you , Miss Woodward ; but I owe a duty to myself and to my husband . You must go in the morning .

div.stage: She moves to return to garden .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Crosses to L. C .Mrs. Parbury !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I suppose I ought to be a lady and go , because you , the mistress of the house , wish me to . But I do n't feel a bit like a lady just now . I only feel like a poor girl whose chances in life are being ruined for a very small and innocent folly .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well , what does all this mean ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Fiercely .It means that I am in Mr. Parbury 's employment , not yours , and that I will take my dismissal from him only .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , I can promise you that .She calls into the garden .Clement !

div.stage: Exit MRS. PARBURY to garden , R .

MISS WOODWARD throws a hard look after her . Then her eyes fall on the broken cup and saucer . She stoops , collects the fragments , and puts them in waste-paper basket . Then she goes to desk , sits and works on proof sheets as before .
Enter MR. and MRS. PARBURY , R .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Working again , Miss Woodward ! Really , you are indefatigable !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm only correcting these proof sheets .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: No doubt Miss Woodward wishes to finish the work to-night , as she is leaving to-morrow .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Leaving to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I think Mrs. Parbury is mistaken .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: To MRS. PARBURY .What do you mean , dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I wish her to go .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I can n't tell you . It is not a thing you would understand . It is simply impossible for her to remain . In her heart she knows I am right .

div.stage: Slight pause . PARBURY goes to MISS WOODWARD .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Are you satisfied here ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Perfectly .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You have no wish to go away ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Not while you wish me to remain .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Do you know why my wife wishes you to go ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Will you kindly tell me ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm sorry I can n't . I 've promised . But —with a look at MRS. PARBURY— I do n't think that Mrs. Parbury 's reasons are adequate .

div.stage: Pause . PARBURY is thoughtful .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: To MRS. PARBURY .Have you anything more to say ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I have only to repeat that it is quite impossible for Miss Woodward to stay .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , I have made up my mind that there is something very foolish under all this , and I shall not allow it to deprive me of Miss Woodward 's services .MRS. PARBURY looks surprised .I do n't mind saying in her presence that she is invaluable to me . I should never be able to replace her .Sense of relief on MISS WOODWARD 'S part .Now , come .Looking from one to the other .What is it ? A tiff — a stupid misunderstanding ? Oh , you women , why will you fuss about little things ? Make it up , do . Think of “ The Roll of Ages . ” Shake hands , cry , embrace , kiss , or whatever your pet method may be . Weep if you like , though personally I 'd rather you did n't . Anyway , as far as I am concerned , the incident is closed .

div.stage: He turns to go .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Doggedly .Miss Woodward leaves this house in the morning .

lg.stage: Looks at his wife for a moment , then turns to MISS WOODWARD .
lg.l: Miss
Woodward , would you be so very kind ——

div.stage: He opens the door for her with great courtesy . MISS WOODWARD bows , and exits L. He comes to C .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Turning to him with assumed brightness .Now , darling , it will be different . Of course , I could n't say much before her . You were quite right to be nice and courteous to her now she is going .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: But I assure you she is not .

div.stage: They are C. MRS. PARBURY takes his arm caressingly .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: But she is — believe me , she is . Of course , we do n't want to be hard on her , and she shall have a month 's salary and a strong recommendation .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Disengaging his arm .My dear Mabel , I absolutely refuse to act in the dark . I hate mysteries . If you care to tell me what all this bother is about , I 'll judge for myself what 's the right thing to do .

div.stage: Sits on sofa .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I can n't — it 's impossible . There are some things that men can n't be trusted to know about . You must leave this matter to me .

div.stage: Sits next him .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: That I quite decline to do .

div.stage: She again takes his arm and talks rapidly , gradually rather hysterically , towards the end appearing about to cry .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Darling , do listen . You do n't understand . You have never been like this with me before . I 'm sure I 'm not asking very much . You can easily get another secretary . Another time you shall have a man one , as you originally wanted to . You were right , dear — you often are .PARBURY rises ; crosses to R. MRS. PARBURY follows him .Darling , do be reasonable . I 've been a good wife to you , have n't I ? I 've always respected your wishes , and not bothered you more than I could help . This is only a little thing , and you must let me have my own way . You must trust me absolutely , dear . You know anything I would do would only be for your good , for you know that I love you .She takes out her handkerchief .I adore you , darling . You must give way — you must — you must !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Stepping back from her .If you cry I shall leave the room .

div.stage: Sits R. Begins to write .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: With her back to the audience , in a low voice .I was n't going to cry .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm glad to hear it .

div.stage: MRS. PARBURY puts her handkerchief away and turns .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I had no intention of crying , dear .PARBURY still writes . Pause . She comes to desk .Shall I write out an advertisement for you , dear ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: For a new secretary — a man .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No . My mind 's made up . I shall not change my secretary .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Clement !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Rises and goes to her .Listen , my dear Mabel . Perhaps I 'm a good deal to blame for the pain you are going to suffer now , and I 'm very sorry for you ; in many ways you are the best little woman in the world . I 've been weak and yielding , and I 've gradually allowed you to acquire a great deal more power than you know how to use wisely .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Really , Clement , you must be raving .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Listen , my dear , listen . What 's been the result ? You 've taken from me my habits . You 've taken from me my friends . You 've taken from me my clubs . You 've taken from me my self-esteem , my joy in life , my high spirits , the cheery devil that God implanted in me ; but , damn it , you must leave me my secretary .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Excitedly walking the stage .Oh , I understand now . You use this exaggerated language , you make these cruel accusations , you work yourself into a passion , because you have grown to think more of Miss Woodward than of me .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Now you know that to be a purely fantastic interpretation of what I said .She takes out handkerchief .I observe with pain , too , that you are about to cry again .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Puts handkerchief up her sleeve , controls her anger , and becomes very determined .You are quite wrong . Probably I shall never again know the relief of tears . Your callousness and obstinacy seem to have dried up all the tenderness in me . Miss Woodward leaves this house in the morning , or I leave it to-night .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Coming to her .Oh , come , come , Mabel , that is too ridiculous .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm very , very serious . Please , for your own sake , understand that . Which is it to be ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: There , dear , let 's drop it now . Do n't you think domestic squabbles like this , besides being boring , are just a little — may one say it , vulgar ? Let 's go back to the garden .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Which is it to be ?

lg.l: Of course , you know I 'm decided . Miss
Woodward stays .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Very well .

div.stage: She goes to bell L. of fireplace and rings . PARBURY goes up , takes a book , and negligently turns over the leaves , secretly , however , watching his wife . Pause until
Enter EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Where is Caroline ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: She 's in her room , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Send her to me , please .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , ma'am !

div.stage: Exit EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I need n't keep you from your friend , Mr. Gunning , any longer .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm all right here , dear ; I 'm perfectly contented .He turns over leaves .There is such a wise passage here . I 'd like to read it to you .She makes a gesture of irritation .No ! Well , it must keep .

div.stage: Enter CAROLINE , L .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Caroline , I shall want you to pack a few things for me .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: What shall you want , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'll come upstairs and show you .
