sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

div.stage: Exit CAROLINE , L. Slight pause .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Rising from his leaning attitude against table up stage , putting down the book , and coming down two steps .You foolish little woman . You know this is impossible . Be reasonable .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Firmly .Which is it to be ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: With a gesture conveys that the subject is closed and returns to his former attitude .I think I have a right to ask what you propose doing .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I propose going home with my father .

div.stage: The laugh of the COLONEL is heard in the garden . Then he appears at the entrance , still laughing . GUNNING appears behind him . The COLONEL enters . GUNNING remains at the window smoking .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: To PARBURY .That 's really the funniest thing I 've heard for years . Have you heard that story , Clement ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What story ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Story of —Then he sees MRS. PARBURY .Oh , quite a drawing-room story , believe me , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Father , I wish to speak to you .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Certainly , dear . What is it ?

div.stage: Crosses to sofa , L. Sits . PARBURY exchanges a look with GUNNING .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Coming down quickly .Mrs. Parbury , I must reluctantly say good-night . Your charming house is almost in the country , and I 've to get back to London . I thank you for ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Interrupting .Please do n't go , Mr. Gunning . It 's quite early , and Clement and you , as such very old friends , must still have a great deal to talk about .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Taking GUNNING 'S arm .No , George , you really must n't go .

div.stage: Leads him up to window , R .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I assure you , my dear chap ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Interrupting .But I make it a personal favour . Dear student of life , stay and observe .

div.stage: They remain up at window .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Dear father , I wish you to take me home with you to-night .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Surprised .Certainly , dear , but ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Do n't question me .Puts her hand on his shoulder .You love me , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Naturally , my dear . But nowadays , of course , I take second place .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I thought so too , but I was wrong . Wait for me a few minutes .

lg.stage: Hesitatingly , after glancing at PARBURY and again at his daughter .
lg.l: One moment , Mabel . This is all so sudden .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Father , do you hesitate to receive me ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Good heavens , no ! But Clement ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Shhh !

div.stage: Puts her hand over his mouth .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Oh ! I was thinking , my dear , that unfortunately there is no mother to receive you now . I 'm only an old bachelor , and you 'll be — er — give me a word .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Kisses him , and goes to door , L. She looks across the room at her husband , and then whispers to herself .He 'll never let me go .

div.stage: Exit , L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: To GUNNING .She 'll not go , my dear fellow .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Humph ! You think not ? Anyway , I must ,

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Do n't .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: The domestic atmosphere is volcanic , and I feel remorseful .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Nonsense , it had to come . You must see me through it now .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: How beastly selfish you married men are !

div.stage: They come down .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Clement , I 'm in a difficulty .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You mean about Mabel , Colonel ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: She proposes going home with you .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Smiling confidently .I do n't think she 'll go .

div.stage: Enter EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: To COLONEL .Your carriage , sir .PARBURY looks uneasy .

div.stage: Exit EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Whistles . Looks at his watch .I think she means it . I ordered my man to wait in the Avenue till he was called . Mabel has evidently had him called .

div.stage: PARBURY is thoughtful .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: I do n't wish to be in the least degree meddlesome ; but , well , there it is !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: The question , I suppose , is what 's it all about ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Well , yes . I suppose that 's it ; although I do n't in the least wish to know .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You hear , George ; what 's it all about ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Down R ., almost angrily .Now , how the deuce should I know ? Colonel , you would be very kind if you would use your authority to prevent Clement dragging me into his domestic difficulties . Married men have a cowardly way of endeavouring to involve their friends . Perhaps you have noticed it .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: I have , Mr. Gunning . My experience of married life extended over a period of twenty-six years .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: May one discreetly express the hope that they were very happy years ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Very happy years , with , however , I must admit , intermittent troubles . Mabel 's mother was one of the best women in the world , but , if I may say so without disloyalty , she was just a little — a little — er — give me a word .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Would the word exigeant apply ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Admirably . Perhaps you have noticed in Mabel the slightest tendency ? Eh ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , well !

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Her mother 's jealousy , too , was something amazing . I hope I 'm not conceited , but in those days I was just a little — er — popular , and perhaps I ought not to confess it , a little — er — give me a word .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Human .

div.stage: They laugh slightly .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: With affected severity .Clement , I hope you are not too human ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quite the contrary , I assure you , Colonel .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Then why — I suppose , after all , it is my duty to ask — why does Mabel come home with me to-night ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: She is simply using pressure to get her own way in a matter in which I think her way the wrong way .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Gad ! they do like their own way , do n't they ? Well , no doubt she 'll be more reasonable to-morrow . I think I may trust you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You may — absolutely .

div.stage: Enter MRS. PARBURY . She has put on a hat and a cloak .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Going to GUNNING .You 'll forgive me , I 'm sure , Mr. Gunning . Good-night . You 'll have Clement all to yourself .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Good-night , Mrs. Parbury .

div.stage: They shake hands . PARBURY joins her , C .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: In a low voice .Do n't go , Mabel . It 's very foolish .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Softening .You could prevent me if you wished .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm opposed to all violence .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Hard again .Which way is it to be ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Firmly .My way , dear .

div.stage: Goes up C. to fireplace .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Alone , C .Good heavens ! He 'll really let me go .Hesitates for a moment , then draws herself up .Come , father .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Good-night , Mr. Gunning . Good-night , Clement . PARBURY and GUNNING . Good-night , Colonel .

div.stage: Exeunt MRS. PARBURY and the COLONEL .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Comes down , a little astonished .By Jove , she 's really going !

div.stage: GUNNING sits . PARBURY stands C ., listening . Pause . Then there is the noise of a carriage door being shut .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Outside .Home !

div.stage: PARBURY somewhat unsteadily lights a cigarette . He then catches GUNNING 'S eye . They look at each other .

sp.speaker: Slow Curtain
sp.p: END OF ACT II .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: SCENE .— The Rose Garden at PARBURY 'S house . A garden table , seat , and chairs . The next morning .

div.stage: Enter MISS WOODWARD . She is dressed simply , but less severely than before . Her hair is dressed more loosely . She carries a little basket full of roses . She places some roses upon the table , which is laid for two for breakfast . She plucks more roses and fastens them in her dress . Meanwhile she hums an air and conveys the impression of being happier than in the previous Acts .
Enter GUNNING , R. He wears a light morning suit , a round hat and brown boots , and carries a stick and gloves .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Good-morning , Miss Woodward .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Good-morning .

div.stage: They shake hands .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Shall I resist the temptation to pay you a compliment ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Gathering more roses .Yes , please .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I thought you would say so . All the same , I feel it to be a deprivation .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Is n't that remark itself the cloven foot of compliment ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Eh — well , perhaps it is . I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: And therefore unlike you .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Unlike me ? What does that mean ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: That it is n't much in your way to pay women compliments .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I hope you are doing me an injustice .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I do n't think so . You have n't a very lofty opinion of women as a sex , have you ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Pretty well — pretty well ; but what makes you think so ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I heard you talk , you know , yesterday afternoon .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh yes ; one does talk a lot of rot sometimes , does n't one ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Embarrassed pause .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Is Mr. Parbury down yet ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: No . But he is sure to be in a few minutes . He is generally early . Breakfast , as you see , will be served here . Perhaps — perhaps you would rather wait indoors .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No ; I 'll stay here if I may . . . . I 'm afraid we made rather a late night of it .

div.stage: He sits .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Three o'clock .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You had much to talk of . I envy people with pleasant memories .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I do n't remember that we talked much of old times . I think we talked of the present .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Rather hardly .Then my envy has flown .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You are right . This affair is rather boring .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Innocently .What affair , Mr. Gunning ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Miss Woodward , you are a triumph of the inscrutable .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Leaning on chair , L. C .I 'm sure that is very clever , because I can n't quite understand it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Quite seriously , Miss Woodward , you interest me more than any person I have ever met .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Do you always say that to girls , Mr. Gunning ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No . Why ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You ought to . I 'm sure it 's very encouraging .

div.stage: She picks another rose .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Doubtfully .Ahem !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Are you quite sure you would n't rather wait indoors ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , quite . I like being here .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: But I 'm sure you find it difficult getting down to one 's level . I often think that the very wise must be very lonely .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Rising .What an extremely unpleasant remark !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm sorry .She sighs .We do n't seem to get on very well , do we ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: With sincerity and coming close to her .I 'd like to get on well with you .

div.stage: Pause . They look in each other 's faces , both at table .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Will you give me a rose ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: No , Mr. Gunning .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Outside .Are you there , George ?

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD gets letters from table .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Outside , to EVANS .Serve breakfast . Enter PARBURY , L . Good-morning . I hope I have n't kept you waiting . Oh , you are here , Miss Woodward . Good-morning .Looks at the table .And you have managed to find us some roses . How very kind of you !MISS WOODWARD gives him letters . He runs them over .No , no , no , no ! Will you kindly see what they 're all about ?She is about to go .Oh , not now — after breakfast will do .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I have breakfasted , thank you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Really ! I suppose I 'm horribly late .Looks at his watch . Then , noticing the roses she carries in her hand .How very beautiful they are ! Look , George !She selects one and hands it to him .For me ? Thank you .He fastens it in his buttonhole .

div.stage: Exit MISS WOODWARD , L .
To GUNNING . ] Lovely , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Gruffly .Yes , it 's all right .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What 's the matter ? Cross ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Not at all . But , really , you married men are very tiresome .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , I see — wanted a rose yourself . Shall I call Miss Woodward back and ask for you ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do n't trouble . I 've done that myself .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You have ? Ha , ha !Begins to laugh , but stops suddenly .Oh !Holding his head .Dear , dear , what a head I have !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You have n't asked after my head .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Sits at table .Your pardon . How is it ?

lg.l: I 'd like to sell it this morning . Do you know ,
Clement , I 'm not quite certain about that whisky of yours .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I am . It 's fifteen years old . Enter EVANS , L ., with , breakfast-tray . But you always had a way of mixing your drinks over-night and growling in the morning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Drawing up his chair .Put it at that , if you like . I do know that I always had a way of disliking you particularly in the morning . I regret I do n't appear to have grown out of it .

lg.l: I 'm so glad . I hate being too popular .
lg.stage: EVANS offers bacon to MR. PARBURY . He pushes the dish away .
lg.l: Take it away . Have some bacon ,
George ?

div.stage: Takes a piece of toast , looks at it , then puts it down .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: Helps himself to bacon .
Exit EVANS , L ., with bacon dish .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I must say I think your display of temper is in the worst possible taste under the circumstances .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Buttering toast .What do you mean by “ under the circumstances ” ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You know what I mean . How much sleep do you think I 've had ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm sure I do n't know . What concerns me is that you detained me in this outlandish place — what county is it ?— till past three o'clock , and then insisted , with alcoholic tears in your eyes , on my returning to breakfast .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Tea or coffee ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Tea — no ; coffee — no , neither .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Have some hot milk ?

div.stage: Offers him the jug .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Ugh ! Do n't .

div.stage: Takes an egg . Shells it .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Lifts the lid of the tea-pot , then of the coffee-pot , and closes them gently with a look of distaste .No , not this morning . Still , we must drink something . What shall it be ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I am your guest .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Perhaps we had better split a bottle .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Please be frank . Do you mean Bass or champagne ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Champagne , of course .He calls loudly .Evans ! Evans !

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Outside .Yes , sir .

div.stage: Enter EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Bring a bottle of champagne .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Starting ever so slightly .Cham ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Irritably .Champagne and glasses .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Recovering his composure .Yes , sir .

div.stage: Exit EVANS , L ., wearing a discreet smile .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: It 's a thing I have n't done for years — taken wine in the morning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Five years .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Exactly .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: In what I may venture to describe as the pre-domestic period it was rather a way of yours .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You mean ours .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Ours , if you prefer it . Where 's the salt ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: There it is , right before your eyes . Why do n't you look ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Pass the mustard , please . What a good chap you were in those days .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes . Strange , you were always ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Always what ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Toast ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Thanks , I 've got some . Always what ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: It 's quite pleasant out here , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Delightful . You were saying I was always ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , it does n't matter .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Of course , being about me it would n't matter .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm afraid of offending you .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You could n't do that .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , I was going to say you were always rather sour-natured .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Really !

div.stage: He takes up a daily paper and glances through it , continuing to do so while PARBURY speaks .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: And that has , I fancy , quite unconsciously to you , I am sure , a disturbing influence on others of happier nature .

div.stage: Taking an egg .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Drawlingly .Yes .

div.stage: He continues to read .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Take yesterday , for instance . Of course , you did n't intend it . I would n't suggest that for a moment . But , damn it , look at the result ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: In the same manner as before .Yes .

div.stage: He reads .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Taking the top off his boiled egg .Simply deplorable . I 've broken loose from my moorings . I 'm at the mercy of every breeze . I feel that I 've lost moral stability . Confound it , why does n't that champagne come ?

div.stage: Enter EVANS , L ., with champagne . Pours out two glasses and hands them to GUNNING and PARBURY .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm not quite certain that for a man like me —GUNNING groans and returns to his newspaper— a man , if I may say so , of generous instincts and large sympathies — a groove is n't a good thing , even if it be a little narrow . Of course , for a man of your nature , it 's a different matter .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Suddenly puts down the paper , draws his chair closer to the table , and takes an egg with apparent cheerfulness .What were you saying , old man ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Affecting heartiness .Let 's talk about you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Fingering the rose in his buttonhole .Dear , dear , how cross you are to-day !

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Excuse me , sir , may I speak to you ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes — what is it ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: It 's about cook , sir .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What 's the matter with her ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Well , sir , so to speak , she wants to know where she stands .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Looks at EVANS , then at GUNNING .How can I help her ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: I mean , sir , or rather she means , now mistress has gone away ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I presume my wife has a right to go away for a few days without cook 's permission .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , sir , certainly . But excuse me , sir ; there 's been gossip . Emma , the ‘ ousemaid , accidentally overheard something between Mrs. Parbury and her maid . Servants is as nervous as race-horses , sir , and cook 's nerves is particularly sensible . So to speak , dismoralisation 's set up in the kitchen .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , you had better go and set it down again , Evans , and do n't bother me any more .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , sir , certainly . Excuse me , sir , I was to ask you who cook is to take her orders from .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: In my wife 's absence , from me , of course .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Not from Miss Woodward , sir ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Staring slightly .Why , has Miss Woodward given any orders ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: No , sir , but cook thought ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: That will do , Evans .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: Exit EVANS , L .
There is a pause . PARBURY and GUNNING exchange looks .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Devilish awkward .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What bores servants are !

div.stage: PARBURY slowly drinks a glass of wine . GUNNING also drinks . PARBURY re-fills the glasses .
Enter COLONEL ARMITAGE , R .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Am I an intruder ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Good-morning , Colonel .He rises and shakes hands .Not in the least .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: At back of table , C .Good-morning , Mr. Gunning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Good-morning , Colonel .

div.stage: They shake hands .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Have you breakfasted ?

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Thanks , yes , but poorly . I did n't get to bed till four .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Nor did I .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Nor I .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: And then I had but little sleep .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: The same with me .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: And with me .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: With a touch of asperity .Your troubles , Clement , you have , of course , brought upon yourself ; but I think it 's a little hard on your friends that they should be made to suffer with you .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Hear , hear !

div.stage: Enter EVANS with fruit . GUNNING and PARBURY each take an apple .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Tapping the champagne bottle with his stick .What 's this ! Some new kind of table water , I suppose .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Champagne .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Champagne at this hour ! Well , I suppose you know best how to regulate your life . Have you an extra glass ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Another glass , Evans .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: Exit EVANS .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: It 's a thing I have n't done for many years .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I trust , Colonel , you wo n't accuse me of leading you from the path of morning abstinence .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Really , Clement , I think this display of ill-humour is scarcely in — er — give me a word .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Good taste .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Exactly ! Good taste , considering that we are suffering from the effects of your domestic — er — er ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Maladministration .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Maladministration — exactly .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I quite agree with you , Colonel .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Look at your friend there . If he 'll allow me to say so , he 's put on ten years since yesterday . Look at me ! Last evening , I suggest — I hope I 'm not conceited — I suggest I did n't look a day over forty-seven .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Not an hour .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: While to-day — what would you say , Mr Gunning ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Looks at him critically , then falls back in his chair .Fifty-two .

div.stage: PARBURY looks savagely at GUNNING , throws his apple on table , and turns away .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: I feared so ; but I like you for your frankness .

div.stage: He cuts a cigar .
Enter EVANS , with tumbler on tray ; he places tumbler on table , and collects the breakfast things . Pause . ARMITAGE lights his cigar with a match EVANS hands him .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: You have n't asked me if I have a message for you .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Prenez-garde !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Loudly .You mean about Newmarket .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: After a glance at EVANS .Yes ; Allerton does n't run any of his horses . Death in the family , you know .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: So I heard . That will do , Evans . You may leave the champagne .

div.stage: They all keep their glasses .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: Exit EVANS with breakfast tray , L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Watches EVANS off ; then to ARMITAGE .Of course , you know , I 'm really most anxious about Mabel . How is she ?

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: I think I told you that I was up practically all night with her .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Was she ill ?

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Bodily , no . We supped in the kitchen at two . It 's amazing how emotion stimulates the appetite . No , Clement , her indisposition is of the mind . She wept .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: All the time ?

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: All the time .Slight pause . Then he adds with a sigh .I had rather a trying night .

div.stage: They all drink champagne ; GUNNING rises , bends over a rose-bush , and hums the air of the music-hall song , “ ‘ E ‘ as my sympathy . ”

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: I 'm not without experience . Poor dear Mabel 's mother , for instance — one of the best women in the world — she would cry at times , and if she got well off the scratch , she was — er — hard to beat . Mind you , I 'll be fair ; I was much to blame — very much to blame . But as for Mabel , bless you , that dear child could have given her poor mother a stone and — er — what 's the expression ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Romped home .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: That 's it — romped home .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Come , Colonel , give me the message .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: I have no message for you . I may tell you , you are not in very great favour .GUNNING smiles .You 're not well spoken of , Clement .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Oho ! Perhaps my wife had a good word for my old friend , Gunning .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: In regard to Mr. Gunning , I think the word “ serpent ” was employed .PARBURY laughs quietly ; GUNNING becomes serious .All the same , I have a message for him .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Really .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Rising .In that case , I 'll get out of the way . I shall be in my study if I 'm wanted .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Comes C .Very well . But I must say , Clement , that I find you , very much to my surprise and regret , just a little — a little — er — give me a word .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Callous !

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Thanks , yes — callous ; and , dearly fond as I am of my daughter , I think I have a right to ask how long you intend leaving your wife on my hands .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Perfectly reasonable — perfectly ——

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Shut up , George !He goes to ARMITAGE .My dear old friend ——

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Interrupting .Hear me out , please . My dear daughter is , of course , always more than welcome to my home , but I trust you will not misunderstand me when I say that I require notice . Since I regained my liberty — I mean , since the death of your wife 's dear mother , I 've drifted into my own — er — little ways . This affair has deranged my plans . Without being indiscreet , I may tell you that I 've had to send telegrams .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Deuced hard lines !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Send her back to me , Colonel . Consult at once your happiness and mine by using your authority . Tell her that cook is in revolt , and that Evans is impertinent . Tell her that I only want my own way when I know I am absolutely right , as in this case . And above all , tell her that I prefer her society to that of a second-class cynic who bellows for champagne at ten o'clock in the morning .

div.stage: Exit PARBURY , L .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: In regard to your son-in-law , Colonel , you have my respectful sympathy .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: A good fellow , but inconsiderate .He lowers his voice .I may tell you in confidence , Gunning , that I had been looking forward to keeping a rather pleasant appointment to-night ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Falling into the confidential manner .Really !

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Yes , rather pleasant — rather pleasant .

div.stage: He takes a miniature from his pocket and looks at it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Leaning towards him .Might one venture to ——

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Keeping the miniature away from him .Oh , no , no , no , no — would n't be fair . Oh , no . Besides , you might know her hus — you might — er ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes , yes , of course ; one can n't be too discreet .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Quickly .Not , mind you , that there 's anything the whole world might n't know , only she — er — she 's not happy at home , and a quiet evening at a theatre — you understand ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Quite , quite !

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Now you , my dear fellow , can do me a friendly turn .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I should be delighted to , but — I do n't see ——

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: I 'll explain . My daughter wishes to see you . She seems to think that you hold the key of the situation .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: But I do n't . I should very much object to .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Never mind — never mind ! See her and do your utmost to make it up between her and Clement .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: It 's no business of mine .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: To put it bluntly , I shall not be able to keep my appointment to-night if I still have my daughter on my hands .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That would be a pity .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: In which case my friend will be vexed — very vexed . I should have mentioned that on her mother 's side my friend is Spanish .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Smiling . Shakes hands .That decides me . Where is your daughter now ?

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: She 's there , my boy , quite close . We walked over the heath together . One moment .He brings a chair forward .Would you kindly lend me your arm ?With GUNNING 'S assistance he mounts a chair , then he raises his hat on his stick .That 's the signal the coast is clear . Trust an old campaigner . There she is ! I say , put that wine away !GUNNING puts the bottle under table up L. C ., and places the glasses on table and covers them over with serviette .It 's all right ! Thank you , thank you !As GUNNING helps him down .Remember , my dear fellow , that I 've trusted you implicitly . My happiness is in your hands . If we men did n't stand shoulder to shoulder in these little matters , society would — er — would ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Crumble to dust .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Exactly .

div.stage: Enter MRS. PARBURY , R. Advancing cautiously , she bows very stiffly to GUNNING , who takes his hat off .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Good-morning , Mrs. Parbury .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Coldly .Good-morning .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Well , I 'll leave you . There 's nothing further I can do for you at present , dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You might stay in the garden and give me a signal if Clement is coming . I have no intention of meeting him under the circumstances .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Very well , I 'll give you an unmistakable signal . “ I 'll sing thee songs of Araby . ”

div.stage: Exit ARMITAGE , L .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Grimly .Well , Mr. Gunning , I hope you 're satisfied with your work .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: My work , Mrs. Parbury — come , come !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , I hope you wo n't dispute that . Clement and I were living together in perfect harmony , in perfect happiness , until you turned up yesterday .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Like a bad penny , eh ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I was going to say like the snake in the garden .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Better still . Our conversation does n't open propitiously . Do n't you think it would conduce to the comfort of us both if we did n't pursue it any further ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Is n't that a little cowardly ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I acknowledge cowardice in regard to other people 's affairs .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Yesterday you were a hero .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Believe me , Mrs. Parbury , you are mistaken . I did n't interfere in any way .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You did worse .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You sneered .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Really , Mrs. Parbury , I ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You aired opinions to me — pernicious opinions . I have a right to assume that you aired the same opinions to Clement , over whom you have some sort of influence .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Not , I think , a good influence , Mr. Gunning . I 've been thinking things over since midnight . Hitherto I 've been obliged to think very little of serious things . Perhaps trouble sharpens the intelligence . I 've discovered that your influence over Clement is the influence of ridicule — the ridicule of the untamed for the tamed .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Say of the disreputable for the respectable , if you like , Mrs. Parbury .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Thank you . That quite expresses my present opinion . Of course it is in your power at least to modify it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I should be grateful if you would show me the way .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You are not sincere .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: ‘ Pon my word , I am .MRS. PARBURY raises her hand protestingly .No , but really — I assure you , dear Mrs. Parbury — I 'm not nearly such a bad fellow as you think . What can I do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Something — anything to remove Miss Woodward from this house .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Miss Woodward ! What has she to do with your quarrel with Clement ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Everything . Sit down .He does so . She makes sure that they are unobserved , then takes a chair next him .Mr. Gunning , strange as it may appear after all that has occurred , I am going to trust you .

div.stage: Lowering her voice .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You are very good .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: That wretched girl is in love with Clement .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Starting from his chair as if shot .What !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Sit down ! Sit down !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Miss Woodward is in love with ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Sit down , please , Mr. Gunning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Laughs — sitting .No , no , no ; I simply can n't believe it .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: It seems such a monstrous absurdity .

div.stage: Laughs .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Drawing herself up .I see nothing monstrously absurd in any one falling in love with my husband . I did !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , of course — a charming chap ; but she 's such an original girl .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Indignant .You infer that I am not ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Not at all , Mrs. Parbury . You are really most interesting .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I do n't think you are very tactful .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm a boor — a perfect boor .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You appear to take an interest in Miss Woodward .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Confused .Only the interest of the student . I still think you must be mistaken .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Emphatically .I caught her in the act of kissing his photograph .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You saw her —Laughs .My dear Mrs. Parbury , a day-dream !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: A fact . When pressed , she did n't deny it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Does Clement know ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: No ; I thought it wise not to tell him .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Heartily .You were right — very right .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm glad you think so .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Some men are so weak .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Drawing herself up again .Mr. Gunning !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: So easily flattered .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: With more emphasis .Mr. Gunning !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: In nine cases out of ten it 's vanity that leads men astray .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: With growing wrath .Mr. Gunning , we are speaking of my husband .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes , yes , dear old Clement has his share of vanity , of course .Aside .Damn him !

div.stage: Rises and goes L .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Rising indignantly .How dare you speak like that of my husband ! A less vain man does n't exist , and what small faults he has concern only him and me — and not you in any way .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I beg ten thousand pardons , Mrs. Parbury . Of course you know Clement far better than I do . Please do n't go .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I shall certainly not remain to hear my husband abused .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: But I assure you ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Crosses to L .Clement vain indeed !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No , no ; a mistake . Do sit down again .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Crosses to R. C .You might , with advantage , look for vanity nearer home , Mr. Gunning .

sp.speaker: MR. GUNNING
sp.p: Perfectly true , perfectly true .

div.stage: He places her chair for her .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: As for the sort of weakness you were good enough to credit my husband with ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Nothing but a slip of the tongue . Do sit down .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: No doubt you have accustomed yourself to judging other men from your own standpoint .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That 's it ; quite true ! You are always right . Wo n't you sit ?

div.stage: She sits . He sighs with relief , then takes a chair himself .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: What do you propose ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm waiting for a suggestion from you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: This brazen hussy ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That expression seems to me to be unnecessarily harsh , Mrs. Parbury .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , of course , if you defend the girl ——

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Pardon me , but I have an old-fashioned prejudice against speaking ill of the absent .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I did n't observe it when you spoke of my husband .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Laughing .Fairly hit . Come , let 's be practical . Miss Woodward must not remain in the house , and Clement must not know the truth . On these points we are quite agreed .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Very well . I 'll see Clement . I have an idea .

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Rises .You 'll not tell him you 've seen me .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Certainly not .

lg.l: Remember above all , it 's most important to our future happiness that
Clement should be the first to give way .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh , I 'll remember that .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: And , Mr. Gunning , if you succeed I 'll try to forget the mischief you 've created , and will ask you to come and see us —shakes hands with him— occasionally .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Thank you so much .

div.stage: Voice of COLONEL ARMITAGE outside singing “ I 'll sing thee songs of Araby . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: That 's father 's signal . I am going to walk on the heath . I 'm far too proud to allow myself to be discovered by Clement here . He might think I want to come back .

div.stage: Exit MRS. PARBURY , R .

Voice of ARMITAGE , still singing , comes nearer until he enters with PARBURY , with the words “ or charm thee to a tear . ” Unseen by PARBURY , GUNNING points out to the COLONEL the direction in which MRS. PARBURY has gone .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: In a low voice , to GUNNING .Will it be all right ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I hope so .

sp.speaker: ARMITAGE
sp.p: Going R .Well , I 'll finish my constitutional . I 'll look in again , Clement , in the hope that you will then be able to tell me how long this extremely uncomfortable state of affairs is to last .

div.stage: Exit ARMITAGE , R ., singing until he is well off .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Give me a cigarette , George .

div.stage: GUNNING hands him a cigarette , then takes a cigarette himself . They both smoke . There is a short silence .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Not a stroke of work . It 's absurd !

div.stage: Throws cigarette on ground in a rage .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You are not happy ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Not particularly .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Then how can you expect to do imaginative work ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quite so !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 've made a mistake , old chap .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You know I 'm your friend .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Apart from all chaff .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes , yes .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Well , you 've gone too far .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Looks at him .You think so ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes . By a petulant discontent you 've precipitated an awkward crisis .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You see it now in that light .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Yes . I 've been thinking things over , Clement .Sits on front of table , C .After all , the love of a good woman is a priceless possession .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You appear to have dropped into the platitudinous .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: With much gravity .Do n't jest , old man , over so sacred a thing .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: After eyeing GUNNING keenly for a moment .You have changed your views since yesterday .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Only the unimaginative never change their views .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You think , then , I 've been wrong ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Very !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I should have gone on putting up with the existing conditions ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: They might have been worse .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Submitting to the old tyranny ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: A wholesome discipline , believe me .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What of our spoilt yachting cruise ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I ought never to have proposed it . Think what a loving wife must suffer under the circumstances — lying awake at night listening to the wind howling in the chimneys and sobbing in the trees . It does n't bear thinking of .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quite so — quite so ! And about our dear old friends whom I was obliged to drop . You may remember you made some very strong comments on my weakness yesterday .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I was hasty . I admit it .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Wybrow , for instance — an awful good chap .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: A tavern wit — a Johnsonian spirit — eminently out of place on the domestic hearth .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , take Carson — one of the best .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Foolishly married a woman your wife could n't get on with . You admitted it .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: But Burleigh — a truly great spirit — your own words .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Burleigh ? It is n't because a man gives you a watch that you need thrust him down your wife 's throat , is it ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What an old fraud you are , George !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Not at all . One sees things more clearly in the morning .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well , since you 've resigned your attitude of nonintervention , what do you advise ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Discreet surrender .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm to send for my wife ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Exactly .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Unconditionally ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Of course . Why impose conditions on a weak , loving , trusting woman ?Going to him .Damn it all , old man , show a little heart .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You know it means the sacrifice of my secretary ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: A little embarrassed ; he drops his cigarette and places his foot on it .It 's obvious that Miss Woodward can n't stay on here in your wife 's absence .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I 've thought of that .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You heard what Evans said . The servants are talking already — and if the servants are talking this morning the neighbours will be talking this afternoon , and the entire north-west of London by the evening .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Quite true — quite true !

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I suppose you do n't wish to compromise the girl ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Certainly not — certainly not !He goes slowly over to GUNNING , and looks him in the face , smiling .And so that 's your secret .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: All this solicitude for my happiness — this sudden change of your point of view — this miraculous conversion of the cynic into the peacemaker — all inspired by a pair of blue eyes . An arrow from Cupid 's bow has winged its way into this wooden heart —Tapping GUNNING 'S chest— and “ Earth has won her child again , ” as Goethe puts it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do n't talk rot !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Do n't be offended . I like it . It pleases me . Think of it ! One dull evening in a suburban home , one morning 's encounter in a rose-garden , and the thing 's done — the sage melts into the man , the onlooker into the soldier . I tell you I like it . It 's so natural , so human — so splendidly unlike you . Let me help . What can I do ? She 's coming here now with some letters for me to sign . “ Were it ever so airy a tread , your heart would hear her and beat . ” Is n't it so ? Shall I speak to her for you ? Better still , shall I leave you alone together ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Fixing his hat on more firmly and taking his stick .I 'm going . You bore me .

div.stage: Enter MISS WOODWARD , L. She carries some typewritten letters and pen and ink . She goes to the table and stands waiting for PARBURY .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: One moment , old man .He looks in GUNNING 'S face , then speaks in a lower voice .Do n't let it pass unrecorded . You have permitted yourself a blush .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Trying to pass him .Do n't be an idiot .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Restraining him .It 's a beautiful , touching truth . The philosopher — the man who has gained perspective — the student who sits perched on a lofty ledge and looks down pityingly on the rest of us , is actually blushing — blushing a poor , simple , human blush !

div.stage: Laughs loudly .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Go to the devil !

div.stage: Exit GUNNING , R .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Turning to MISS WOODWARD . He goes to her .Forgive my laughter , Miss Woodward , but it is n't often one surprises a philosopher in a blush . Now , let us see !He sits and takes the letters . MISS WOODWARD remains standing by him . He reads . Interrupting himself after a moment , he laughs slightly .Dear old George !He continues reading , then signs the letter . He looks over another and says “ Excellent ! ” and signs it . Then he quickly signs the other letters , sits back in his chair , and saysThank you !MISS WOODWARD gathers up the letters .I 'm afraid that 's all the work I can do to-day . I 'd like to have gone on with the novel , but it seems the mood wo n't come .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm very sorry .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: The day is out of joint .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I wish I could do something .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No , no , do n't you trouble . It 'll all come right presently . By the way , what a good fellow Gunning is !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Is he ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Do n't you think so ?

div.stage: Looking at her .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 've seen so little of him ; but I 'm sure he must be if you think so .

div.stage: She is going , L .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Wait one moment , Miss Woodward . I know there was something else I wanted to say to you .She comes back .He rises and paces stage thoughtfully .Oh , yes ; I know ! I 'm afraid my domestic complications have made things a little uncomfortable for you here .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Astonished , drops the letters on the table .I do n't — do n't understand .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I mean that you probably feel it rather awkward to actually live — night and day in the house in my wife 's absence ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Blankly .Oh , yes , yes ; quite I suppose .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Not looking at her .I do n't know much about these matters ; but I do know that you women are very sensitive , and apt to worry about what people might say .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: In the same manner as before .Yes — of course .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I thought so . Well , it has occurred to me that perhaps under present circumstances it would be better if ——

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You mean for me to go away .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: In a low voice .If I had been wiser I would have expected it .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I mean , of course , to sleep only . Mrs. Howlands at Parkhurst House just down here lets some of her rooms I know , and probably she has a vacant bedroom now . I 'll send down presently and see what can be done . In fact , I 'll send Evans now .

div.stage: Is about to go L .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Mr. Parbury !

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Stopping .Yes .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Do n't send , please .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , I see ; you would rather go yourself .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I would rather go altogether .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Amazed .You would rather go altogether !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I mean I will go altogether .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Miss Woodward , what is this for ? What have I done ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Nothing that has n't been perfect kindness to me .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Then why wish to go now ? I know I can n't expect to have you always , because you will some day get married .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I shall never get married .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Nonsense ! Of course you will , and the man who gets you will , in my opinion , be a very lucky fellow ; but until that day I certainly looked forward to having the benefit of your services .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm sorry if I disappoint you . Please forgive me and let me go .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: But really , Miss Woodward , I must beg for some sort of explanation . Last night you acknowledged you were perfectly satisfied . You wished to remain .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You have unconsciously shown me to-day that I was wrong .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Indeed ! I would be glad to know how . Oh , how weary one gets of mysteries !MISS WOODWARD 'S head droops lower .He walks the stage , then looks at MISS WOODWARD and pauses ; he goes to her and speaks more gently .I beg your pardon , I fear I spoke impatiently . Do understand that I only wish for your own good . I admit in our relations I 've hitherto been rather selfish . I 'm afraid writing men are prone to be so . I 've allowed you to study my wishes and feelings and nerves all the time , without giving any thought to yours . I 'll try to be more considerate in the future if you 'll only regard me as an elder brother and tell me what is troubling you now .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm sorry , but I can n't . I 'm ashamed that you should worry about me at all .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Is it anything to do with Mr. Gunning ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Nothing at all . How could it be ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Miss Woodward , I do n't like to press you , but this general cloud of mystery is seriously affecting my nerves . At least tell me — I make it a personal favour — the cause of the quarrel between my wife and you .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: It 's impossible ! Mrs. Parbury may tell you after I 've gone . I 'd rather you despised me then than now .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Wonderingly .Despise you ?

div.stage: Their eyes meet . Pause .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Passionately .Please do n't — do n't even try to guess .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: The light breaking in on him slowly .I think I understand .

div.stage: MISS WOODWARD turns up stage and stands with head bowed , her back to the audience . There is a long pause . At first PARBURY does n't appear ill-pleased . He looks down at the rose in his buttonhole , and begins to raise it half-tenderly to his face . Then his face becomes grave , and he slowly removes the flower from his coat , and places it on the table against which MISS WOODWARD is standing . He takes one of her hands .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I do n't ask anything — I do n't guess anything , my dear child — my little sister . I was wrong to press you to tell me your trouble ; for what could a hardened , rough-natured man do with the secrets of a young girl 's heart ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Do n't speak like that ; only say that I may go .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Goes up C .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: Sees the rose where he has placed it . After a slight pause she takes it up . During the following , she slowly picks it to pieces , dropping the petals on the ground .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Coming down to back of table and speaking very gently .I suppose there must soon come a time to every girl of heart who goes out alone into the world — a time when life seems to press hardly upon her and weariness of the unaccustomed stress makes her heart falter , and when she longs to take rest for a time in the old childhood , in the home she perhaps once thought to be dull and dreary , in the mother 's arms that have always been ready to open with love for her .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Do n't !

div.stage: Sinks into chair , R. C . ; buries her face in her hands .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Perhaps you feel that that time has come now . If so , go home for a little while , and get rest and fresh strength for the battle of life . Come back to the fight soon . You are bound to succeed , because you have talent and ambition and courage .Slight pause . He takes her hand .Do n't cry . There is nothing you have lost or suffered yet quite worth a tear — Enter MRS. PARBURY , R ., GUNNING , and ARMITAGE . — nothing quite worth a tear .He is bending towards her .

div.stage: MRS. PARBURY , who is slightly in advance of ARMITAGE and GUNNING , stops near MISS WOODWARD and PARBURY , brought up short by seeing their intimate position . PARBURY draws back from MISS WOODWARD , who remains upright and motionless . GUNNING and ARMITAGE , who exchange glances , remain L. MISS WOODWARD crosses L. to go .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: In a low voice , speaking slowly , with deep emotion .I suppose — I have still a right to ask — for some explanation ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Of what , dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Of this familiarity .

lg.l: You should n't mistake sympathy for familiarity . I was only giving Miss
Woodward some advice about her affairs .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: What affairs ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I said her affairs , dear , not ours .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: If that is all the explanation ——

div.stage: Turns away L .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Mr. Parbury very kindly and very properly advised me to go home for a time —She comes down to MRS. PARBURY and speaks to her alone— and I — I descended to your level — I cried !

sp.speaker: Quick Curtain
sp.p: END OF ACT III .

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: SCENE .— Same as Acts I. and II .

div.stage: Upon the curtain rising , MISS WOODWARD is discovered at the desk . A luncheon gong is immediately heard . MISS WOODWARD looks up and listens for a moment , then shrugs her shoulders and resumes her work . She opens a drawer of the desk , glances at its contents , and then writes .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Writing .Drawer four . Reviews favourable of “ Harvey Masterton . ” In top corner , tied in bundle , reviews unfavourable .She closes and locks that drawer and unlocks another , into which she looks . Writing .Drawer five . Proof sheets of new novel corrected to page 180 . At back , accounts with publishers .The luncheon gong is struck again . She opens another drawer , looks into it for a moment , turns over its contents , then shrugs her shoulders and writes .A variety of photographs of Mrs. Parbury and two packets of letters marked “ Private . ” How touching !She closes the drawer with a bang , and opens another .

div.stage: Enter EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: C .Excuse me , Miss , but have you heard the luncheon gong ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Yes , thank you .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: It 's been struck twice , specially for you , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Who told you to strike it the second time ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Mr. Parbury , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: And who sent you now ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Mrs. Parbury asked me to tell you they 're at lunch . They 're the only words that 's been spoken since they sat down . It 's rather trying to the nerves , Miss , waiting on people that only open their mouths to eat .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You will please say that I do n't wish any lunch .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Has Emma packed my things ?

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: She 's packing them now , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Glancing at an A. B. C . which is on the desk .Will you please order a cab for me at — let me see —consulting the book— four-twenty — say at half-past three .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , Miss . Excuse me , Miss , but we 're all very sorry you 're going — particularly cook . Cook 's very strong in her attachments .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Looking into a drawer .It 's very kind of cook .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Cook 's words was , “ This 'll be a dull ‘ ouse when the little sunbeam 's gone . ”

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: That will do , Evans .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Excuse me , Miss , it was meant kindly . We was all on your side in this embroglo .

div.stage: A pause . MISS WOODWARD is obstinately silent , and goes on working .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Ca n't I get you something , Miss ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Yes ; ask cook to kindly make me a sandwich , and I 'll have a glass of beer .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Sandwich of mutton or ‘ am , Miss ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Ham , please .Exit EVANS , L .It 's sure to be cold mutton to-night .She writes .Old manuscripts .Closes drawer .There , that 's all in order for him .Rises .I know there are some books of mine here . I may as well have them .Goes towards book-shelves , but stops when she comes to the occasional table on which is the photo of MR. PARBURY . She stretches out her hand and takes the photograph gingerly . Then she looks round to see if she is observed , with to herself an affectation of fear .Poor thing ! Was it outraged by a kiss ! What a shame ! But it 's all right now !Puts it back with care .No one shall hurt it . It 's perfectly safe — perfectly safe .She goes to book-shelf .Keats — mine .Takes a volume .Matthew Arnold — mine . Enter EVANS with sandwiches , beer , & c ., on a small tray , which he places on the desk . Jane Eyre — mine . I think that 's all .Brings the books down and places them on desk .Thank you , Evans .

div.stage: She sits .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Cook thought you would care for that piece of cake , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I would . Thank cook for me .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , Miss .He goes to door .There 's still a hominous silence at the lunch-table , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Taking a sandwich .That 's all right , Evans .Exit EVANS , L .After all , one must have food .She takes a respectable bite out of a sandwich .And who could over-estimate the consolations of literature ?Opens a book and reads .“ Is the calm thine of stoic souls who weigh Life well , and find it wanting , nor deplore , But in disdainful silence turn away , Stand mute , self-centred , stern , and dream no more ? ” Yes , Mr. Arnold , it is .

div.stage: Takes another bite of a sandwich .
Enter MRS. PARBURY , L .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Why wo n't you come to lunch , Miss Woodward . But oh , I see you 're having something here .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: For a moment slightly confused .I — I —Drinks some of her beer— I have a railway journey before me .

div.stage: She rises .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: All the more reason you should come and lunch properly .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You are very kind , but I am in no mood for merriment .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Merriment !

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Are n't you all merry ? I 'm so sorry . I thought it would be all right now that I 'm going away .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'm afraid that wo n't make any difference . You speak as though you thought you had a grievance against me .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Oh no ; I suppose it 's the other way about .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Perhaps it ought to be , but somehow I do n't feel it acutely . I feel only a dull pain . It 's a terrible thing , Miss Woodward , for a young married woman to suddenly realise that her happiness is gone . I feel that I have aged many years in the last few hours .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: So do I. I 'm sadder , but healthier .

div.stage: Finishes the beer .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: It 's so much worse for me .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Oh , of course our own troubles are always the worst . That is what has been called “ The vanity of grief . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Well , Miss Woodward , I 'll say good-bye . I bear you no ill-will now — really I do n't ; and I shall always be glad to hear that you are doing well , although naturally under the circumstances I can hold out no hopes of your coming back here .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: In amazement .You , Mrs. Parbury , hold out hopes of my returning here ! Do you think there is enough money in the Bank of England to induce me to do that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I did n't mean it unkindly . I was only trying to say a nice womanly thing , and to show you that I did n't blame you so much for falling in love with my husband .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I never did .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , Miss Woodward , you know I saw you here .Pointing to PARBURY 'S photograph .It was the greatest shock of my life .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You mean I kissed his photograph ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: You know you did .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: With a little laugh .I suppose I did .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Then how can you say ——

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Gravely .It was a motherly kiss .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Turning away .It seems impossible to talk with you . I used to think you a serious-minded person .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Please do n't go , Mrs. Parbury , I 'm quite serious . I 'd like to explain . I think I owe it to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Turning .Well ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You will let me be quite frank ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh , I shall like it .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'll take the risk .Comes down L ., sits on sofa .Go on , please .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: The interest which I began to take in Mr. Parbury sprang in a way from what has been called the maternal instinct .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: If you go through the world exercising your maternal instinct on other women 's husbands , Miss Woodward , you 'll end badly .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I do n't propose doing so . I 'm going home to try it on my sisters .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: If you had known anything of life , you would have seen that I had sufficient of the maternal instinct for the needs of my husband .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm very , very sorry ; please do n't be angry , but I did n't think it found the right expression . It was very impudent of me , I know .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: It seemed to me that you smoothed his hair when he 'd rather it was rough , and roughed it when he 'd rather it was smooth .Demurely .I think that expresses what I mean . I have a beastly sly way of noticing everything , and I began to feel sorry for Mr. Parbury . And being quite as egotistical as most girls , I began to think I should have made him a better wife than you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Oh .

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Perhaps in the remotest corner of my heart I think so still .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Indignant .Well ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: But I never loved him — never in the least degree .

div.stage: MRS. PARBURY , during the foregoing , has listened with anger gathering in her face , but at the end , after an apparent momentary struggle with herself , she bursts into laughter .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm glad you 're not angry .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Still laughing .It 's impossible to be angry . And so because you thought his wife bored him , you gave his photograph a nice motherly kiss . That was very sweet of you , I 'm sure .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: It was well meant , Mrs. Parbury ; and you must always remember that I did n't know you were looking .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Laughing , sits on sofa .Why do you make me laugh when you must know that my heart is breaking — that I have lost my happiness for ever .Pause . She begins to laugh again . Rises .And I thought you a designing hussy , when you are only a very quaint and harmless girl .

div.stage: Laughs .
Enter GUNNING , L .; keeps the door open .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm in the way .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Not at all . We have said all we had to say to each other . Oh , how that girl has made me laugh !

div.stage: Exit MRS. PARBURY , L ., laughing . GUNNING shuts the door .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Gunning .

div.stage: Gathering her books together .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I want a little talk with you .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm sorry I can n't give you the time ,

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh yes , you will , Miss Woodward .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Indeed ? I admit my position is a lowly one , but that does n't lessen your presumption .

div.stage: Goes towards the door .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: With conviction .You wo n't go .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: But I will .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: My dear Miss Woodward , believe me , you will not .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You do n't propose using force , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No ; I think you would like me to , but unfortunately this is not our house , and one must observe the convenances .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Going to door , L .Good-bye , Mr. Gunning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Moral force will detain you .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: What moral force , pray ?

div.stage: Turning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Curiosity . You know you are dying to know what I have to say .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Indeed I am not .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Oh yes , you are . And further , a certain womanly graciousness will prevent your going . You are saying to yourself , “ Mr. Gunning has evinced a genuine interest in me . It would be cattish of me to refuse him a few minutes ’ talk . ”

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Slowly comes to sofa and puts her books down .I certainly do n't wish to be cattish .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Sits on sofa .And anyway I want to eat my piece of cake . Will you pass it , please ?He passes the plate .Thank you . I hope you wo n't mind my eating .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Not at all . I like it .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Not that I fear it would make any difference if you did .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No , certainly not . Go on being natural , please .Pause . He watches her nibbling the cake .Shall I ring for a fresh piece ?

lg.l: No , thank you . I 'm used to this piece now .
You need n't be disconcerted , Mr. Gunning .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm not a bit .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You look it a little .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do I ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: And you know you did n't detain me here to watch me eating cake .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No , although you do it very nicely . I want to ask you what you think of me .

div.stage: Leaning on back of chair , R. C .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I have n't thought of you .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Well , I 'd like you to begin .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I 'm afraid I have n't time now .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: It might be to your interest , though I do n't say positively that it would be .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Explain .

div.stage: Turns to him .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I think I ought first to tell you something about myself .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: In mock alarm .Not the story of your life , surely . My cab will be here soon .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You told me yours last night ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You asked me to . I have n't asked you .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You need n't reproach me for taking an interest in you .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I do n't ; but you make such a fuss about it , as if it were a sort of miracle .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Crossly takes plate from her lap and cake from her hand ; puts them on table , R .Oh well , I suppose I ought n't to detain you , Miss Woodward . You are evidently anxious to get back to your twelve sisters and the hat and frock you told me about .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Rises .You need n't throw the family poverty in my face , although it serves me right for giving my confidence to a comparative stranger .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Miss Woodward , I humbly beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Although the home may be grubby , I daresay we are as happy as you . We believe in things , anyway — you do n't .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Do n't judge me by a hasty remark . Besides , I had an alternative to suggest .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You ? You do n't want a secretary , do you ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I — I wanted to tell you in a different way , but you wo n't let me . I want you as my wife .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Your wife , Mr. Gunning ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: It may appear sudden and cold-blooded — but your cab is coming .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: You 've taken my breath away . How exciting it is when it does come . I really do n't know what to say . I know there is a usual thing . It is n't “ To what am I indebted for this honour , ” is it ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I do n't know . I 've never asked a girl before .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: We do n't know each other in the least .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That 's where we would start with a big advantage . We 'd have all the pleasure of finding each other out . Anyway , you are not displeased .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Oh no ; either way I score . If I say yes , I suppose I 'll make a good match .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Pretty good .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: And if I say no , I shall at least be able to boast of a proposal .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: That 's so .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Not that there 's much satisfaction in that to a practical mind .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: No ?Goes to her .Try the other .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: But we do n't love each other .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Another big advantage . Love is the rock upon which so many well-intentioned young persons split . They engage to marry each other while the intelligence is perverted , the reason unbalanced , and the judgment obscured by an overpowering sentiment . They enter into a solemn life-binding contract in a highly emotional and altogether unnormal moral condition . The disastrous results of such folly we see examples of daily . We will escape that snare .He comes close to her .Of course if the sentiment should subsequently come , if that particular kind of emotion should by chance supervene , we 'll deal with it as best we may .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Sits on arm of sofa .Still there must be something in love-making . I remember my sister and the curate seemed to have a very good time . We all thought them fussy , but I know they liked it .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I made love to you in the garden this morning .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Did you ? I thought it was pity , and resented it

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: You refused me a rose , and gave one ——

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I refused you because I thought you pitied me , and gave one to Mr. Parbury because I pitied him .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'd like you to pity me .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: I should if I said yes .Leaves him .But I mean to say no .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Following her .You are afraid .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Of what ?

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Of what people call my “ nasty sneering way , ” for instance .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Confidently .Oh , I could deal with that all right .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: I 'm sure you could .Goes near to her .Say yes , Hyacinth .

div.stage: Enter EVANS , L .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Your cab is here , Miss .

lg.stage: To MISS WOODWARD , in low voice .
lg.l: Send it away .
Do .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Thank you , Evans . Let it wait .

div.stage: GUNNING moves away to C. with a satisfied smile .

sp.speaker: EVANS
sp.p: Yes , Miss .

div.stage: Exit L .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Gunning . If you were entirely different from what you are , I think I could have liked you ; or if I were entirely different from what I am , I think I might have married you . But you are hopelessly modern and cold-blooded , and I am only an old-fashioned , healthy English girl , and a healthy English girl does n't want to make experiments , she wants to be loved .

div.stage: Suddenly GUNNING throws his arm round her , and bends forward to kiss her . She quickly raises her clenched hand as if to strike him in the face . He looks her in the eyes without flinching .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: Perhaps she wants a master .

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Softly .Perhaps .

div.stage: Her hand slowly drops ; he kisses her .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Outside L .No , my dear ; I can n't wait any longer .

sp.speaker: GUNNING
sp.p: In a low voice to MISS WOODWARD .The garden . Will you come and find me a rose ?

sp.speaker: MISS WOODWARD
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Enter COLONEL ARMITAGE , L ., MRS. PARBURY , and MR. PARBURY .
MISS WOODWARD and GUNNING exeunt quickly to garden , R .

MRS. PARBURY comes down L. and sits on sofa . PARBURY goes R. and sits , ARMITAGE remains C. They are all silent and uneasy . A considerable pause , during which they are occupied with avoiding each other 's eyes .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: A cheerful day .

sp.speaker: MR. PARBURY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Very .

div.stage: Another uneasy pause .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Well , I must be going .

sp.speaker: MR. PARBURY
sp.p: Do n't go .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Please stay , father .

div.stage: Another pause .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: With much irritation .Well , you see I 'm staying .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: MR. PARBURY
sp.p: Thank you , Colonel .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: But I should like to know what the devil for ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Father !

sp.speaker: MR. PARBURY
sp.p: Colonel !

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: I really think I have cause to be angry . A more depressing function than your luncheon party to-day I 've never experienced . I think I have a right to a little cheerfulness in my middle age . I 'm sure I 've earned it . I 've had a great deal to put up with in my life .

sp.speaker: MR. PARBURY
sp.p: No doubt , no doubt .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Of course I have always accepted my full share of the blame . That I have felt to be only right and manly .Pause . He looks at CLEMENT .As for my late dear wife , her heart was rarely deaf to a proper expression of regret . The memory of her I feel to be a blessing to this day .He blows his nose sympathetically .One thing I can tell you , Mabel , that when your dear mother and I made it up — well , we did make it up . I am not without some very agreeable recollections — most agreeable .Pause . He comes to MRS. PARBURY .I trust you wo n't require me tonight , my dear . I have to attend a Masonic Banquet .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: No , father ; I sha n't want you .

sp.speaker: COLONEL
sp.p: Then good-bye .Aside to her .Be true to your own good heart . Your dear mother was — sometimes .He kisses her , and then goes to PARBURY .Good-bye , Clement .Aside to him .Bear up ; I 've been there myself .He goes — aside at door .Rather tactful , I think — rather tactful .

div.stage: Exit L .
There is a constrained silence . MRS. PARBURY is particularly uneasy . After a moment PARBURY rises , lights a cigarette , and stands at mantelpiece .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Am I in the way , dear ? Do you want to work ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: No .Rises , goes up R .To-day must be a holiday .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Holidays are meant to be happy days .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: I suppose so .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Our happy days have gone . I suppose they will never come back .

div.stage: Very sadly .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: It would be wiser to look for new ones than to weep over the old ones .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I 'll not cry , dear ; I promise you that .Pause . Suddenly rises and turns to him .Clement , can n't we start again ?

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Perhaps . But we must consider first where we now are and the direction in which we should go .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: Perhaps in your heart you are blaming me more than I deserve — I mean about Miss Woodward .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: You chose to keep the motives of your conduct a secret from me .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I may have been wrong . I saw her kiss your photograph .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: Starts slightly .Why did n't you tell me ?Pause .Why did n't you tell me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
sp.p: I thought — I thought it would be wiser not to .

sp.speaker: PARBURY
sp.p: What have I ever done to earn so low an estimate of my character from you — that I am not to be trusted with the knowledge that a foolish girl had kissed my photograph .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARBURY
